people.
STRUGGLE FOR
THE BODY OF A
DEAD SENATOR
While Mrs. Snyder Claims the Remains of
John S. Enos the Widow Gets an In
junction Preventing Inter
ment. .
SONOMA, April I.â Funeral services were held this morning at 11
o'clock over the remains of the late Senator John S. Enns at the
residence of Mrs. R. J. Snyder, at which place he dropped dead last
Wednesday morning-. Many of the dead man's friends gathered to
view the corpse and hear the impressive sermon delivered by Rev.
R. Wylie of Napa, The last will and testament of the deceased was
opened beside the bier and read by ex-Senator Pinder of San Fran
cisco. In the will $5000 is left to. the dead Senator's daughter, Mrs. Ger
tie C. Willis, his gold watch and chain to his nephew, John Summerfield
Enos, and all the remainder of the property to his. friend, Mrs. R. % Sny
der. It also reads that Mrs. Snyder is to take charge of the remains
and dispose of them at her will. Attorney Lippitt of Petaluma is
named as executor without .bonds. A request is also made in the doc
ument that he should not be burled until four days after his death,
and it is signed by Attorney Charles A. Garter of San Francisco.: .
The body is still at the residence of Mrs. Snyder, who holds pos
session of it. The holding of these services, however, does not settle
the sensational question of what will be done with the body and who
is the legal claimant. When Senator Er.os left his wife about eight
years ago he broke all connection with her and his daughter, Mrs.
Willis, and refused to recognize either of thorn, .although there was
never a divorce granted! Since then he has resided the greater por
tion of his time with Mrs. Snyder on her ranch, one mile east of this
place, while his wife has resided in San Francisco. â¢ . .
SANTA ROSA, April I.â The sad, strange spectacle of a wife strug
gling for possession of the lifeless body of a husband she could not
hold while living, a noble daughter endeavoring to do all remaining
in her power to preserve the few straggling remnants of a father's
reputation and save his memory from being perpetuated in a role in
which he seemed almost to glory while alive and well, was presented in
the courts here to-day. The story back of it all is one of the strang
est in the history of the State.
Last Wednesday ex-Senator John S. Enos, one of the best-known
residents of this part of the State, where he had lived many years,
suddenly dropped dead. At the time of the sudden death he was just
entering the yard of Mrs. Rachael Jane Snyder, a rich and beautiful
widow, living near the historic old town of Sonoma, and with whom
his name has for years been linked by the whispered tales that fly
from ear to ear. In fact, this phase of the case was notorious through
out the entire section. The body was taken in charge and all arrange
ments for the funeral made, when Attorneys Haven and Haven of San
Francisco filed with the County Clerk papers in a startling proceed
ing. They, on behalf of their clients, prayed the court for an imme
diate injunction to prevent Mrs. R. J. Snyder, the defendant named in
the action, from burying the dead body of the ex-Senator, and to com
pel her to deliver the aforesaid remains into the possession of the plain
tiffs, Mrs. John S. Enos, Mrs. Gertrude C. Willis and William Willis.
The complaint alleges that the plaintiff, Mrs. Susie Enos, who uses
his name in the papers of the case, is the surviving widow of John
S. Enos, who died as related above; that the plaintiff, Gertrude C.
Willis, is a daughter and only child of the deceased; that the defend
ant, Rachael Jane Snyder, has in her possession the dead body of the
husband and father, 6aid John S. Enos, and has no moral or legal
claim on the same; that plaintiffs applied to said defendant for pos
session of the dead body of the deceased that it might be given hon
orable burial, whereupon said defendant refused to surrender to plain
tiffs, or either of them, possession of the dead body, but informed
them that she herself would superintend and direct the burial. The
complaint further alleges that the defendant, Mrs. Rachael Jane Sny
der, has no claim of any kind whatsover upon the body of the de
ceased; that upon the plaintiffs devolved the duties of burial and prep
aration for burial of the deceased, and that the defendant, Rachael
Jane Snyder, is preparing and threatening to bury said deceased upon
her own private premises and not in any cemetery whatever, and
will so bury him unless restrained and prevented by order of the court
The injunction prayed for was granted, and papers were served by-
Sheriff Allen at 2 o'clock this morning. By the terms of the order
made by the court. Mis. Snyder was directed either to turn the body
over to the plaintiffs forthwith, or at once appear in court, and show
cause why she should not do so.
Mrs. Snyder has refused to give up the body of the dead and bases
her claim to the right to retain the possession upon the following pro
visions of the will left by the deceased: "I direct that my body shall
not be burled until four days after my death, and that the manner
time and place of my burial shall be according to the wishes and direc
tion of Mrs. R. J. Snyder."
The case occasioned the greatest conceivable amount of comment in
this section. Both Enos and Mrs. Snyder have lived in this county
many years. . .-'':.
Mrs. Snyder, beautiful and rich, came first into notoriety some five
years ago, when her brother, Perry Sears, was on trial for the mur
der of his sister's foreman, John Reibli. On the occasion Mrs. Sny
der fought her brother with a hatred that was almost frightful, and
it is alleged used her every effort to either have him hanged or sent to
tho penitentiary. .
Attorney E. S. Lippitt of Petaluma was retained as special coun
sel by the sister to assist in the prosecution, and during the trial of
the case Sears is said to have used every effort to blacken his sis
ter's character. Since that time the relations between Enos and Mrs
Snyder have been common talk. A short time ago, it is said, Enos had
about arranged to be taken back by Mrs. Enos, an estimable lady but
failed to go when the time came.
ANTE-ELECTION
DIE IN TEXAS
While Bands Are Playing
Editor Brann and Cap
tain Davis Fight.
During the Exchange of Shots
the Principals Are Mor
tally "Wounded.
Criticism of a Newspaper and a Bitter
Political Rival Cause the
Street Tragedy.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
DALLAS, Tex., April I.â A special to
the New,s from Waco, Tex., says: In
the midst of busy preparations for city
election meetings, while bands were
playing 1 and scattering handbills from
their decorated vans, calling the people
together, W. C. Brann, editor of the
Iconoclast, and . Captain M. T. Davis
met and fought a revolver duel to the
death. The combatants met just at 6
o'clock this afternoon on Fourth street,
in front of the Cotton Belt ticket office,
end, after exchanging a few words,
both began emptying their revolvers
Into each other's bodies.
When the battle was over, Brann was
found to be perforated in the left lung,
the left leg an,d the right foot. Davis
was shot through the right lung and
through both of his arms. The sur
geons say both men are likely to die.
The difficulty between the two men
grew out of the Brann-Baylor feud of
last year. Captain Davis' daughters
are pupils of Baylor University, and
the references made in the Iconoclast
to Baylor, which were generally con
strued to mean reflections on the moral
character of the pupils and faculty,
brought forth from Captain Davis a
denunciation of Brann, delivered In
language most forcible and direct. In
the city campaign now in progress
Captain Davis is the chairman of one
The facsimile /# -S/fEZrT *<* â¢ry wrapper
â  â¢ignature of Wu&Â¥Z7c&&fr4S of * CASTOEIA.
..'â â -- .. ~ â  â -"..â â
of the committees, and was active all
day in the duties that the position en
tailed. Election day is close at hand
and excitement is high. Brann waÃ an
advocate of the candidate Captain
Davis was seeking to defeat, and that
Btate of affairs contributed to no small
extent to the meeting.
Politics, however, was not the chief
cause, by any means. About a month
ago, before the city campaign opened
a friend of Brann's referred to him in
complimentary terms in the presence
of Captain Davis, and nearly provoked
a row then and there. Remarks on
that occasion made by Captain Davis
as to the Iconoclast and its editor
were repeated, it is said, in Brann's
hearing, and Brann's rejoinder was
carried to Captain Davis. This epi
sode stirred up the men against each
other and increased the bitterness be
tween them, which began when the
Brann-Baylor trouble arose and greAv
intense when the Gerald-Harris trag
edy occurred last November. It was
often predicted that when Brann and
Captain Davis met there would be
bloodshed, Captain Davis being a fear
less man and ready on all occasions to
express himself.
The publications of Brarin against
Baylor University wounded him deeply
and he took every occasion to make
his feeling known. This afternoon
Brann and his business manager, W
H. Ward, were opposite the street to
gether, goi-ng in the direction of
French's bookstore, Captain Davis
office being between the bookstore and
the Cotton Belt office. When Brann
and Ward reached the front of the
bookstore Captain Davis was in front
of his office. The words that passed
between them were words of reproach
and they lost no time in getting- out
their weapons.
About ten seconds were occupied in
the shooting, at the end of which Brann
and- Davis lay bleo<Hng and W II
Ward, Brann'a business manager was
shot through the right hand, the bones
being shattered.
A wild bullet hit Motorman Kennedy
on the knee. Kennedy was passing on
his car. Another wild bullet hit Eu
gene Kepler in the foot. The wild bul
let wounds are not serious. Kepler
and his partner, Prince, are touring the
world on a wager and had just reached
Waco. A reporter visited Brann after
he was shot. He was at home on a
couch surrounded by surgeons, his in
tellectual face as white as snow. His
wife any many friends were with him.
He is too weak to talk and is proba
bly past ffurgery, although the doctors
say there is some slight chance for his
recovery.
Captain Davis was taken to the Pa
cific Hotel nnd is regarded as mortally
wounded, his right lung being cruelly
lacerated. Both men are bleeding in
ternally and are faint. At a late hour
both men were alive, but appeared to
be sinking.
STOCKMEN
ARE AROUSED
Nevada Raisers Cry Out
Against Infected
Animals.
Refuse to Permit the Admission
of Cattle and Sheep From
California.
Federal Authorities 'Will Not, and, In
Fact, Cannot, Interfere With tho
State Quarantine.
Special Dispatch to The Can.
CARBON, Nev., April Iâ This morn-
Ing George Nixon o-f Wlnnemucca
reached Carson to confer with th'
Governor in regard to the enforcement
of a rigid quarantine against the ship
ping of cattle from the infected dis
tricts of California. George Russell and
Thomas Hunter came with Nixon, all
representing the Elko County cattle
Association. Mr. Nixon came to con
sult with the Governor on the necessity
of enforcing- the quarantine laws of
Nevada regarding cattle and sheep. The
Governor assured Nixon that the law
would be rigidly enforced and there
would be no laxity on the part of the
State authorities ip the matter. Tha
following dispatch waÃ received from
Elko:
ELKO, Nev., April 1. 1898.
Governor Sadler: It would be cheaper
to buy Miller & Lux's cattle and destroy
them In California than allow them to
i come In. Enforce the law and save us
from perpetual ruin.
ELKO AND TUSCARORA MERCAN
TILE COMPANY.
By E. S. Farrington.
The following was sent to James
Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture:
CARSON', Nev., April 1. 1898.
James Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture,
Washington, D. C: The cattlemen of
this. State are a unit Jn opposing the ship
ment of cattle from infected districts into
t this State, and its authorities will use all
: the means at their command to prevent
such shipments, as well as to remove
forthwith from the State all shipped.
REINHOLD SADLER, Governor.
It is reported that bands of sheep
amounting to 250.000 are on the way
from California approaching the border
lines of Nevada. The sheep law of this
â  State enables each county to protect
'â  itself in such instances. County Com
missioners have the right to appoint
inspectors to turn back and quarantine
' all sheep from the infected districts.
The following dispatch was sent to the
i Commissioners of counties lying adja
! cent to California:
â¢ Ample protection against the shipment
of diseased sheep into this State is af
: forded by the statutes of lÂ«03, page 37.;
REINHOLD SADLER, Governor.
Secretary Wilson wired the Elko Cat
tle Association as follows: "The de
partment will not nennit the admission
of the cattle from infected portions of
â  ] California, unless the Nevada authorl
â¢ ties request such action."

MARKET ST. Sf.^i*^THE CAPITAL CITY OF NEVADA.
CARSON. Nev.. April I.â The 111 j
wind that has blown the clouds
out of California's sky and with
the clouds the rain that is dun I
California's farmers has immense
ly Improved the prospects of Carson
v. In all the valley there are no
attle for sale. All have been dis
posed of and at excellent prices. For
d;iys past two and three carloads of
cattle a day have been shipped from
:>Te. Hundreds of tons of hay have
been sent out of ihe valley within the
past month at prices more than double
what Carson Valley ranchers received
lu.Totofore.
The quality of timothy hay raised
near Carson is of a peculiar v.xcellence.
Once upon a time Haggin & Tevis be
lieved it economy to get the supply
for their racing stable from Carson,
though it cost them $200 a ton by the
time it had reached New York. Ne
vada's capita] is not dependent for its
prosperity upon the mills or the mines,
the State and national institutions or
the farming country, of which it is tho
center. It is the condition of all these
interests united which disposes the Car- (
sonite to believe that the turning point '
has be^n reached and prosperity lies
staight ahf ad. Carson possesses all the
attractions with which Nevada en- j
dowa her most favored cities. It has f
the river and the mountains. It is i
level ;md tree-shaded. Its supply of '
spring water comes from the
ntaina behind. It is well known '
that when Nevada waterâ like a cer- j
tain celebrated little girl who wore
curlsâ -is good, it is very good. And
n's is of the best. As i<~> the
Lte of Nevada's capitalâ though it
Lced itself and Nevada last March i
trnishing what is now known as
prizefight weatherâ the physician at j
ate's Prison, located here, reports
â -hat in four years there has been but;]
:tMth among the eighty convicts. !
I arson's climate is at least as mer
to the just as to the unjust.
ANENT HoME ENTERPRISE.
It is years since this particular %ec
tiqn >>f Nevada has been in condition
anything like what it is to-day. A
u.-r!< ago Carson organized an im
ement club, to which the best men j
ir tho town belong. The club proposes .:
.iid up the place, to encourage
Ivome trade, to reach a 'lo.OOQ mark in
population. Years ago Carson women
:-'!M'osed it impossible to supply their
households and their wardrobes here.
They sent outside the State for gowns
â  .! bonnets and furniture. Nowadays
patronize Ormsby County mer
tis; as a result the Carson store
rs are keeping a better class of
Is and their prices are more reas-
The merchants have become
:iatred to reach out for more busj- j
They advertise nowadays fully
twice as much as they used to. And
the next link in the commercial chain,
the newspapers, are issuing extra edi
tion?âan innovation heretofore un
known in Nevada â and increasing their
circulations throughout the country.
The Pine Nut excitement comes just
at the right time to lift Carson upon !
a wave of success. Within three days :
2000 acres of land have been taken up
near what was known as the Zirn
mine, twenty miles from Carson, where
a pocket of ore assaying $60,000 a ton
was found some years ago, and "old
Zirn," as Carsonites call the discoverer,
made his fortune. And then a sudden
end came to the golden tale. For min
ers hitherto at Pine Nut have been
repeating the experience of the ,
early Comstock miners, with this
difference, that the Pine Nut prospec- .
tbrs have been seeking for quartz and
scorning placer.
ORMSBY COUNTY'S MINES.
On California placer mines that pay
IS or 20 cents to the cubic yard divi
dends have been declared. The Pine
Nut gravel extends over 700 acres to a :
depth of more than 60 feet and is worth
$4 a cubic yard. If Pine Nut were lo
cated near Dawson City there'd be a j
stampede up at the Klondike. People
In Carson are deeply Interested in the ,
Pine Nut region. They may well be; j
for if half what is claimed for these !
wonderful placers Is true, Carson's <
Improvement Club will have to raise !
its mark. Ten thousand people will not |
content it two years from now.
An Interesting fact in connection
with the Pine Nut mines is the pres
ence in Carson of James M. Wishart
of Oakland, the inventor of a goid-Bav~J
ing machine, a sort of improved rocker
which the management of the Pine Nut
mines will adopt, provided that tests
to be made early next week at the j
mines shall be as satisfactory as those >
FAVORS THE
CABLE PLAN
Hawaii's Legislature Has
a Bill for Aiding the
Company.
Permission Under Certain Con
ditions Granted the Pacific
Promoters.
According to the Scheme the Rates to
Japan Will Be 9O Cents and
Here 33 Cents a Word.
SpÂ«"-!ai Correspondence of The Call.
HONOLULU, March 24.â A bill has
been introduced in the Hawaiian Sen
ate to authorize the construction of a
cable by the Pacific Cable Company,
known as the Scrymser Company,
whose bill in Congress was favorably
reported on by a committee of the
House several weeks ago.
The bill gives the exclusive cable
rights to the islands for twenty years.
H must be laid within eighteen months
the passage of the act by the
American Congress, and extended to
Japan within three years. It must be
capable of transmitting fifteen words
a minute. The rate between here and
the United States is not to exceed 35
cents a word and to Japan not to ex
â 'i W) cents. In case of v-ir the Presi
dent may seize the cable and exclude
all messages he sees fit. A guarantee
of $2fÂ»,000 in Government bonds is to be
put up by the company.
In accordance with the recommenda
tion of President Dole and the Senate
ncÂ« Committee the salaries of the
cabinet ministers have been increased
from ?4000 a year to $GOOO.
The Senate has massed a bill relating
to the registry of foreign-built vessels.
It rf-strliis the issuance of registers of
vessels to citizens or corporations not
having a place of business and having
'â  made on Carson's principal street a
week ago. The machine saves all the
fine gold by a: unique mechanical con
trivance. It requires only a cr.-nstant
flow of 2^ inches of water to work
seventy yards of gravel In twenty-four
hours. Five tons of gravel an hour
was the rate at which the machine
worked, and repeated tests failed to
show a trace of gold in the tailings.
"If this Wishart ma.chine will do â¢
at Pine Nut what it has done in Car
son," said the secretary and treasurer
of the new company, "'its adoption at
Pine Nut is assured." ..
But Pine Nut with all its marvelous
possibilities is not Ormsby County's
one mineral hope. The mines at Buck
eye, ten miles away,; are attracting
much attention. There are 1640 acres
of the Buckeye property which will av
erage $1 a cubic yard. Out of 600 cubic
yards $1392 worth of the gold flakes
Carsonites are admiring as bottled ex
hibits just now was obtained. And to
day comes news of a strike at Jumbo,
twenty-two miles in the other direction
from Oarsan. On the streets the rumor
is that $5000 to the ton is the quality of
the ore taken out. There seems to be
a belt of placers half encircling this
valley. And with the development, the
awakened interest in mining another
Comstock, a golden one, is one of the
probabilities.
FROM SAGEBRUSH TO SUGAR
BEET.
The Alpine Land and Reservoir Com
pany is another cause that will aid in
the development of Western Nevada.
The most capable men in Carson are ;
carried on such business within the re
public for the two years' immediately
preceding such application for registry.
Declaration must also be made by cor
porations, as for individuals, that no
aliens are interested in the vessel or
its profits or issues, except those who
may own capital stock of such corpora
tion. The act is not to affect existing
registers.
One registration case is now pending
and several more applications are ex
pected within a week. Colonel Macfar
lane some time ago asked for registry
for the Peter Jebsen, a Norwegian ves
sel of 1000 tons, now in the Nanaimo
coal trade. The Amorapoora, now fly
ing the British flag, will also ask for a
Hawayan register.
The United States steamship Mohican
arrived on the 19th, nine days from
San Francisco. She brought ammuni
tion and supplies for the naval vessel
at this port. The United States steam
ship Baltimore will leave for Hongkong
this afternoon or early to-morrow
morning.
Captain John Good, who was dis
honorably discharged from the Ha
waiian military service about two years
ago. has asked President Dole for a new
trial, on the ground of newly discovered
evidence. Captain Good claims that he
can exonerate himself and asks for a
court'of inquiry.
The legislators in the Senate will not
listen to the terror-stricken cries of
warning sent forth by their qunodam
supporters of the American League of
the close approach of next year's elec
tion, and the inevitable destruction of
the annexation party, and possibly of
the republic, at the ballot-box in Sep
tember, 1899, when, to use the words of
the president of the league, "There will
be a deadly revolution, but not of bul
lets, but of ballots," which will sweep
away every legislator into political
oblivion who opposes the people's will
in their desire to make this a popular
republic instead of a military oligarchy
controlled by corporations of Asiatic
employing planters and the "family
compact."
The tremendous power wielded by
some of these plantations is aptly il
lustrated by an incident occurring in
the Supreme Court on Monday last.
A German contract laborer named
Johan Viercke, working at the Liliue
plantation (for which the imperial Ger
man Consul's firm is the Honolulu
agent) was taken before a district
magistrate on Kauai and sentenced for
the use of threatening language under
the grossest of provocations â he was a
married manâ to the luna or overseer.
He was brought to Oahu jail, and thoro
he might have lingered until he had
served his time of one year's imprison
ment, then to return to the plantation
and serve out another year for the one
lost in prison, had it not been for the

VIEW OF CARSON CITY, LOOKING EAST.
SLUICING IN THE PINE NUT REGION.
Independent ifone of whose editors has
been. fined $200 and another $1 for libel
for exposing the situation at that
plantation), whose friends sued out a
writ of. habeas corpus.' The case was
well handled by Messrs. Humphreys
and Gear, the latter a brother of Rep
resentative Gear of the. United States
Congress, and the whole bar was in
tensely interested. Imagine the sensa
tion in court and the mortification of
the Justices of the Supreme Court, who
justly pride themselves upon the im
maculate administration . of our Ha
waiian laws, when it was ascertained
that the offense the man was charged
with was no offense at all within the
purview of our laws. And this was but
the first and weakest objection made to
the illegality of the conviction. Of
course the man was promptly liber
ated and left with his weeping wife
and child. And what redress has this
penniless, pitiful man? An appeal to
his Consul? He states that his Con
sul's (the plantation agent) reply to his
appeal was:. "Don't trouble me. You
know you are guilty and have behaved
bailly. Go back to the plantation im
mediately and go to work. H
(mentioning the name of the luna) has
another complaint to make against you
and you will again be arrested." The
Germans here., except the plantation
element,, are furiously indignant, and
the whole matter has been referred to
the Minister of Foreign Affairs at
Berlin.
Salaries of Officials Cut.
SAN JOSE, April I.â The Board of Man
agers of Agnews Asylum recently made
the following cuts in salaries of the asy
lum officials:- Secretary T. S. Montgom
ery from $100 per month to $50, Steward
F. C. Young from $150 per month tn $133,
Medical Director Sponogle from $3500 per
year to $2000, Storekeeper B. C. Shartzer
from $75 prr month to $50. the assistant
physician from $2500 to $2000 per year and
the seamstress from $50 per month to $45.
It is provided that $100 per year be added
to the salary of the secretary, steward
and medical director until they shall re
ceive their original salary.

has resulted in a great demand for pas

acres .of tule pasture land in Sutter Coun
ty yesterday.

NEW LEASE
OF LIFE FOR
COMSTOCKERS
Seven Great Mining
Companies and the
Sutro Tunnel.
Agreement Reached at
Last After Many Years
of Negotiations.
While Divided Against Itself the
Lode Was Threatened With
Extermination.
NOW THE OUTLOOK IS ROSY
People of Virginia City Feel That a.
Turning Point In the Comstock
Has Been Reached.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
VIRGINIA CITY, April I.â One of the
most important events that has oc
curred in the later history of the Corn
stock mines was consummated In San
Francisco on Thursday last, and news
of it has just reached here. On that
day representatives of the seven great
mining companies of the Comstock met
Franklin Leonard, the president of the
Sutro Tunnel Company, and an agree
ment was reached by which the differ
ences heretofore existing between the
mining companies and the tunnelpeople
were settled, and an amicable arrange
ment entered into by means ot which.
members of this company, which Is |
headed by the Governor uf this State, i
! The company owns 5000 acres of land :
i in Douglass and Ormsby counties which j
! will be worth from $20 to $50 an acre j
I when irrigated. The company's reser- j
voir is in Alpine County; and despite;
j the pooh-poohing of capitalists whose ;
j enterprise consists in banking their .
! money, steps will be taken within the i
j near future to change a sagebrush em- ;
: pire into farms which will support 2000
i farmers. Sugar-beets is to be the
watchword of the Alpine Company
! after the necessary $50,000 has been â¢
; raised to buy up rights of way, etc. The
! late Governor Jones superintended ex- I
! perimental planting of beets in various
! parts of Nevada. It was found that
â  beets raised in this sagebrush land pro
i duce 1" ncr cent sugar, 5 per cent more
1 than the average on the coast.. The
! comparative cheapness of the land
I here, the vast territory which will be â¢;
: irrigated from the company's reservoir '.
seem to assure Nevada's pre-eminence j
as a future beet-sugar country.
THE OCCIDENTAL COLONY.
A most interesting experiment in col- j
onization is furnished by the Occiden- j
tal colony in Smith's Valley forty miles ;
from here. The colony has been in j
existence six months. It consists of i
sixteen familiesâ over eighty people, j
Each member of the colony paid $150
into the common fund. They incorpor- ,
! ated, elected officers to serve them, who
I receive $1 a dayâ jur,t as every mem- i
i ber of the colony does, who works and
1 earns that sum. In the half year these i
the various mines along the lode enter
into a sort of partnership with the tun
nel company.
There were present at the meeting
Charles H. Fish, representing the Con
solidated California and Virginia; Su
perintendent Kervin for the Gould and
Curry; George W. Wells for the Sav
age 1 H. M. Gorham for the Chollar and
Potosi, and W. E. F. Deal, the attor
ney for the Best and Belcher and Hale
& Norcross, besides President Leonard.
Concessions were made on both sides.
President Leonard has always been de
sirous of bringing about this union of
interests between the mines and the
tunnel which will practically give the
Comstock a new lease of life, and
whose ultimate effect is likely to be far-
reaching.
Negotiations have been going on in
this connection for the past two years.
Contracts have been all but signed,
only to be abatidoned. Proposals for a
compromise have been rejected first by
one side and then the other, and the
Comstock, divided against itself, was
threatened with extermination. The
papers which are being prepared by
Attorney Tausky are to be submitted
for the signatures of the various com
panies and to President Leonard. Then
they are to be sent on to New York
for the approval of the directors of the
tunnel company.
The success of the plan is highly
probable, and that the various parties
interested have been able to reach so
satisfactory a conclusion is the best
news that Comstockers have heard in
years. The working of the upper levels
of the Comstock mines, the carrying off
of waste rc-ck through the Sutro tunnel,
is the natural, the most direct and eco
nomical mode of procedure. Where the
tunnel taps the Brunswick lode, the
territory which has been in dispute,
there's ground worth fighting for. Hap
pily for Virginia City, the powers that
hold its fate in their hands have come
to a peaceable settlement, and people
here feel that a turning point in the
affairs of the Comstock have been
reached. __________________
MUTUAL RESERVE SUSTAINED.
! An : Injunction to Prevent Collection
of Assessments Is Beaten. ;
NEW YORK. April 1. â The application
i of Charles Schoolhouse.a policy holder, of
! i the -Mutual Reserve Fund j Life Associa
! tion, foi an injunction to restrain the as
; sociation from collecting, its \ assessments
I as recently ; reapportioned , came up ; for
' hearing in the Supreme Court on Wednes
â  day, and was fully argued by counsel for
! both parties. : After a full discussion of
; the facts and of : the ; legal ; questions mi
i . volved \ the , court â¢. refused to grant ;an i in
â  junction â  on ; the ; grounds I that . the ' plain
tiff as a policy holder had no standing
'to â > maintain such 'an action ; that i it ; did
4 not appear that the plaintiff load, euffer.ea
people have spent In Smith's Valley
these . hard-working empire-builders
have constructed a tunnel 440 feet long,
only seven men being spared from the
fields for three months' time to per
fect the difficult task. Before this the
ditch that supplies their land "was con
tinually failing them. Now a splendid
provision of water is assured. At pres
ent they have 100 acres in wheat. 300
acres of alfalfa, and an apple orchard
which will yield $1500. They have filled
the school at Wellington with their
children. The success of the Occiden
tal colony is instructive. They have had
hard times. It has taken the closest
economy to reach the point where they
are now. They have still to live
through the months till harvest time.
The construction of that tunnel has vir
tually been the sacrifice of 100 tons of
produce that might have been raised.
But they are people of determination,
of exceeding industry. The 5300 acres
they own are capable of supporting
them all most comfortably. They have
ten years' time to pay the $12,000 they
owe. But in six months they have
practically created $5000 worth of prop
erty. The end of their first year here
will see the end of the worst of their
struggle for existence, and hundreds of
families in California, Dakota, Ne
braska and Pennsylvania, who are
watching and waiting for the assur
ance of the permanence of the Occiden
tal colony, will follow in the footsteps
of these men and women.
A great point for the success of col
onization In Nevada is the fact that
the Central Pacific Railroad has over-
or was In danger of such an injury as
would entitle him to an injunction; that
all of the allegations of the plaintiff were
â fully denied and overcome by the de
fendant's affidavits; and "because the
granting of an injunction Would be pro
ductive of great mischief and injury to
the association in the. prosecution of its
business.
AFTER A COURTSHIP
OF MANY LONG YEARS.
E. K. Hall, a Rancher of Salinas Val
ley, Aged 78, to "Wed Rebecca
Liebrandt, Aged 72.
SALINAS, April I.â County Clerk Kalar
this afternoon issued a marriage license to
the oldest couple ever married here. The
cortracting parties were E. K. Hall, a
prominent rancher near Bradley, aged 78,
ami Rebecca Liebrandt, aged 72. Both
the groom and bride are well known peo
ple and have resided in Salinas Valley
over thirty-five years. Neither has been
married before, and they have been
courting for some ten years.

OTHER AIDS TO PROSPERITY.
At Carson are located many State
and national institutions, the combined
appropriations for which amount to
many tens of thousands of dollars an
nually. The State Orphan Asylum, the
j State Prison, an Indian school, the car
shops of the Virginia and Truokee Rail
road, the Mint, the State printing of
; flee are among those that contribute tn
the prosperity of the town. Recently
the amount of borax and so :1a shipped
to California and the East lia.s in
creased considerably. Carson's boat
factory competes with those of Cali
fornia, supplying Riverside and Red
lands with boxes for all their oranges*
and sending boxes even to South
America. Carson Valley potatoes re
ceived first premiums at Nmv Orleans*
at the Centennial, at the World's Pair.
New Orleans hotel keepers send fop
their supply of- potatoes ail the way to
Sagebrushlahd.; An Ormsoy County
farmer shipped a carload of apples taÂ»
.Scotland a few weeks ago. The flour
mill here is turning out fifty barrels a
day. Three new brick stores have been
erected lately^ Carson'y athletic club
ij flourishingi numbering over a hun
dred members and supporting a gym
nasium from which, it is the purpose
of the club, decisions in matters ath
letic shall issue to rule the world of
pugilism. Carson intends to dictate a
new code of rules; and when once a
pugilist is ruled out of the ring by thÂ«
Carson Club his standing as a prize
fighter will be forever forfeited.
Such is the extent of the city's pros
perity that the CarsOn Appeal â after
twenty years of kerosene lightingâ has
introduced gas into its office and there
are wild rumors to the effect that Sam
Davis contemplates a new ceiling and,
âif the mines of Pine Nut prove all
that is expected of themâ possibly clean
walls.
HARVEST OF DEATH
IN SANTA CRUZ COUNTY.
Three Well-Known Persons of the
City Suddenly Summoned, and
a Rancher of Aptos.
SANTA CRUZ, April I.â Four people
of prominence have died in Santa Crua
the past two days. Fred Grasso, aged
52, and a prominent Italian citizen, died
at his ranch near Aptos.
Miss Lizzie Webb died last night at the
home of her father, George Webb. She
was 30 years of age and a native of Eng-
Mrs. Sophia Lukens, one of the best
known women of this city, died shortly
before 2 o'clock this morning. She wa*3
a native of Springfield, 111., and leaves a
husband. Evan Lukens, and three chil
dren. She was 57 years old.
This morning the sad death of Miss
Fannie Crawford occurred. While dress
ing she fell to the floor, death resulting
from heart trouble. Miss Crawford was
a sister of Mrs. Dr. Gordon, nnd has been
prominently connected with the Christian
church. : .
FIERCE MOUNTAIN FIRE
RAGES NEAR ST. HELENA.
Sulphur Springs Threatened by a
Conflagration in a Forest
Tract.
ST. HELENA, April I.â A fierce
mountain fire has been burning for near
ly a week on the McÃuer property,
two miles from town. A great deal of
timber has been destroyed, and several
dwellings are in danger unless the prog
ress of the flames is checked. The fire
is moving toward Sulphur Springs, and
should it reach that place nothing could
be done to prevent the destruction of the
buildings, as there is no fire apparatus
there. A smaller fire is burning on the
mountains between here and Calistoga
and threatens to do much damage.
Hill Hopes for Reprieve.
SAN QUENTIN PRISON, April I.âBen
jamin Hill, the Oakland wife murderer,
whose execution is set for April 6, will
be transferred from murderers' row to
the death chamber to-morrow morning.
Hill is in no way cast down and hopes
for a reprieve or commutation of sentence
to life imprisonment.
Mrs. Hannah Eastham Dead.
WOODLAND, April I.â Death has been
busy among the old settlers of Yolo
County of late. Mrs. Hannah Eastham,
a native of Massachusetts and 65 years
of age, died Thursday night as the result
of an apoplectic stroke.

THE EBBING OF THE TIDE,
' I ' HAT travel toward Alaska is falling off is. ari |
I established fact, and people are trying to ac- j
* count for it. One reason given is the prbSpfec- :
tive war with Spain. It is far from being acceptable. !
When a man becomes inoculated, with the gold fever â 
he is riot .likely to stay at home for the purpose of]
shouting for the old flag, nor give up tlie prospect j
of. a fortune so as to be enabled to get a slash from
an unfriend.! y machete. It is. not : difficult ; 'to. undefV
stand, however, that the stories of death along
northern trails, of starvation attd frost, and. the
gloomy reports of those who vainly sought to win
glittering plenty there, ntjght easily, tend to check
the malady and at last clear the system entirely of: the
fever microbes. â  ;
COMMISSIONERS IN LUNACY;
BY reports from Sacramento it appears that the
State Commissioners in Lunacy, as a. result Jot
their consultation in this city, have .decided '
upon a. series of economies in. the asylunis of the
State which will result in saving, according to: pnÂ£
account, $14,000, and according to another $17,000,
annually. '."'â â ',-,â â  â¢â  ,y ; .. '\ â â 'â ':â 
A saving of such magnitude in State insthuiibns
voluntarily undertaken by the men who: have charge
.. of. them is something so unprecedented. that tq-'prac-*.]'
tical politicians it will seem like evidence that Com-. '
missibrrers. in Lunacy are very much the same as 'l
lunatic Commissioners. The seeming, . how-evef, is I
on the surface only. It appears frorii the â¢ details of |
the plan of economy proposed that as much cafe has]
been taken of the big men in the asylums and, the j
Commissioners themselves as the most astute tax- j
eater desire, and that the economies are to be i
. accomplished solely at the expense of the men. who
receive small salaries, and whose positions, being j
largely under civil seTvice regulations, are not avail
able for patronage.
The reports state the Commissioners have agreed
that the medical superintendents and assistant phy
sicians, all of -whom are now receiving good large j
salaries nnd free board and lodging at the asylums, j
are to get ah increase of pay amounting, to: $100 for j
each year's continuous service, and each 6f them is !
further allowed one servant at $25 a month. Thus;
far there is no saving to the State, Something had |
to be done to make up for the increase of pay to the â¢
big men and for the employment of private servants
at the expense of the commonwealth. The pruning
knife of cutting economy was therefore applied to j
the wages of the subordinate officials, and: the thing
was done. .--.' . ; ' . . "â â¢â¢' ;' 'â¢ â ' â  - â â¢,.
The Commissioners in Lunacy have followed, the
precedents that have prevailed in this world since
ever man was first given power to pay Peter at the ;
expense of Paul. The trick of showing generosity [
to one set of men by practicing economy on. another
is one of the accomplishments of men in authority
which was reduced to a fine art generations ago.
Nevertheless it has never become popular. A Lori
don fishwife when reproved for swearing at an eel
for squirming when she was $kinning it alive de
fended herself by saying that as she had been skin
ning eels for twenty years it was time for them to!
get used to it arid quit squirming,: The eels, how- I
ever, have never got used to it. Neither has man- <
. kind got used to the economic plan of skinning sub- â 
ordinates, which the Commissioners in Lunacy have '
seen fit to follow. They are still squirming. â¢ j
A few years ago Mr. Pullman tried the plan on an
extensive scale at the town of Pullman. In order to !
maintain the large salaries paid to the heads of de- j
partments in his business and at the same time save j
enough to enable him to give $100,000 to a church ;
for the worship of the good God, he reduced the!
wages of every workingman in his employ. The re- j
suit was that memorable squirm which agitated the I
whole nation and led to serious civil disturbance. !
It is evident, therefore,:; that this method of prac- 1
ticing economy is -trot acceptable to. the American
people. Californians will gladly. see a reduction of
expenditure*; in- the. various institutions of the State, j
but they will- not approve a plan which provides big j
officials with private servants, at the expense of the
State and takes the cost out of the pockets of men
who have been working for small wages and have
neither servants nor perquisites. â¢ " . â¢
If the policemen accused of cowardice prove them- â¢
selves to be as brave as lions and retain their posi : '
tions, they owe it to the community at least to learn !
how to shoot. As a sort of preliminary practice they !
might go down to the beach-, and. taking careful aim, ,
see if they could not in time learn to hit the wide and ;
smiling sea, '.
One day we hear that the Kaiser is friendly to
Spain, and the next that he intends pressing money
claims against the country. In this uncertainty it is I
possible to escape being perturbed by reflecting that j
nobody cares which story is true.
THE PRESIDENT fIND THE CRISIS.
ALL reports from Washington lead to the con
. elusion that, the President has given ample
.. assurances to the. leaders of both houses that
there will be no delay, hesitation or weakness on the
part of the administration in dealing with the Cuban
crisis. The President has sent his demand to Spain
and has been waiting only for the answer.
That these assurances have been of the most ex
j plicit and definite kind is made evident by .the effect
they have had upon the majority in. both houses of
Congress. In the Senate the Committee on Foreign
Affairs has decided to make no report on the* war
! resolutions introduced during the week until Mori-
day, having determined to wait absolutely on the
, President's wishes. In the House the speeches of
i Thursday, taken in connection with the vote of the
1 preceding day 'on the Bailey resolution, show con
clusively that the Republicans of that body are in full
accord with the administration and are confident that
the message will be satisfactory to the party, the
people, the nation and the civilized world.
This confidence on the part of the members of
both houses, many of whom are in daily communi
cation with the President, is sufficient to give an
j equal confidence to the people at large. Mr. Gros
j venor, who is almost a personal representative of
the administration on the floor of the House, stated
!on Thursday: "Cuba will be free, and Cuba will be
free by the intervention of the United States. I
! would not give one cent for a declaration of inde
pendence unaccompanied by a further declaration.
What nonsense it would be to declare the island of
Cuba independent and then let her starve to death!
The thing to do in the case of Cuba is. to exhaust
all that diplomacy can. do to achieve her liberty and
independence, and, failing in that, stop not at the
half-way house the gentleman from Texas (Mr.
, Bailey) is talking about, but declare her indepen
i dent and accompany the declaration with an a-my
iand a navy to make our declaration worth some
! thing." â  ; â¢'.'
After that speech there can be little doubt of what
the event will bring forth. Either we are to have a
message announcing Spanish acceptance of our
terms, or. a message calling upon Congress to pre
pare for war. In either case Cuba will be free.
While all this is in itself gratifying to the people
and is satisfactory as far as it goes, there is still want
ing one thing, and that is a clearer expression of
what is to be done in regard to Spanish responsibility
for the destruction of the Maine. The majority of
the American people have noted with indignation
that both the. President and Congress have shown
an inclination to subordinate the Maine disaster, to
the Cuban crisis. That should not be done. The
war spirit of the American people was aroused not
by the reports of suffering in Cuba, but by the blood
of the victims of the Maine and by the treachery
and cowardly cruelty that caused their deaths. For
that crime the cry of justice and of patriotism is for
vengeance, and whatever may be done for Cuba the
message of the President will fall short of fully sat
isfying the country if it neglects this demand of the
popular heart.. . . =
THE PROFITS OF FORESTRY.
:'.\. :TE have referred to.' the need of proper admin-
WE have referred to need of reserves. It
istration of the Federal forest reserves. It is
â¢â .\..'r' not : - unlikely : that in the future these re
:serves may yield a revenue needed by the treasury in
I excess of the . cost of. their administration. An ex
â¢ ample of this is furnished by the small kingdom of
. : I Bavaria, with 5.000,000 people in. an area only one
! fourth that of California. The Bavarian forests
j cover 34 per cent of her area, and are owned one
. third by the kingdom, half by private parties, and
' the' rest by villages and: other corporations, the total
â¢forest land being about 6,000,000 acres. Of this 46
I per cent is stocked with spruce and fir, which is har
j vested at an average age of 120 years. Of pine there
is 30 per ".cent, mostly used for firewood and har
vested at 80. years. The remainder is hardwood,
mostly beech,' harvested at 120 years, and white oak
for tanbark;- used at years.
â  The Forester, to which we are indebted for these
I facts, notes the yield per acre. "Groves 100 years old
! cut 10.000 cubic feet per acre. The poor and rocky
I mountain land yields 4000 cubic feet. In the
state forests the growth equals about sixty-one
j cubic feet per year, " so that they furnish an annual
i harvest of 120,000.000 cubic, feet of timber and fire
! wood. The private forests, due to less exact care,
grow at the rate of fifty-four cubic feet per acre per
; year-
The effect of superior care of the .state forests is
shown in the increase of annual growth. In 1829 the
cut was thirty-five cubic feet of wood over five
inches. â¢ In 1850 the cut was forty-four cubic feet, in
\ iB6O, forty-eight, and' in 1896 sixty cubic feet.
â  . In 1850' fully 84 per cent of this cut was firewood,
i but. this inferior class was only 67 per cent in 1880,
and the superior, cut is steadily increasing. The net
income of the state forests in 1850 was only $1 per
acre, but has increased to $1.92 per acre. This in
â  come on the state's forests of 2.091,930 acres amounts
now to nearly $4,000,000 annually over all expenses.
Of the cost. of administration only 10 cents, per
j acre, or 8 per cent of the income, is required for re
1 planting, while 50 per cent goes for supervision and
j 30 per cent for cutting and logging.
A steady supply of timber is furnished for hun
j . dreds of mills and cheap firewood to all the people
j from these preserved forests. The net income at a
I 3 per cent rate makes the state forest property worth
$130,000,000, or $65 per acre, while the land without
j forest would not be worth $10 per acre.
Measured by this example we may estimate the
j enormous. mine of wealth there is in our American
! forests. If they are properly preserved and cared
- J for their area may be constantly increased, their crop
i be made permanent, and the supply of timber, lumber
! and firewood made to increase every year to supply
i the wants of a growing population. Unless we adopt
I this policy our forest area will annually diminish.
I the supply decrease as the need of it increases, and
I the date of the total disappearance of American for
ests can be definitely fixed.
According to a yellow paper McKinley will go
"crashing down the ages." There is no reason to be
lieve it. The good old fashion of thundering down
has never been changed by legal enactment, and even
this fashion has not been generally followed. The
difficulty of either crashing or thundering, and keep
ing it up century after century, is apparent. New per
sons get born. Sonic of them grow up and develop a
desire to thunder or crash themselves, and they won't
let the bones of their ancestors get in the way of it.
Some of the stories about clever robberies per
petrated in Skaguay by "Soapy" Smith should break
the monotony by an additional chapter detailing the
lynching of that enterprising person. That "Soapy"
is engaged in robbery wherever he is may safely be
taken for granted.
THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1898.
FOREIGN OBJECTIONS TO AMERICAN
PRODUCE.
f~* ONSULAR reports issued by the State De
l partment in the March volume contain an un-
usually large, number of reports of opposition
i-toi -to American imports into foreign countries, lhe most
j notable of these come from Scotland and Germany
and disclose not only a present antagonism to the
importation of goods from this country, but a feeling
that is likely to lead to further and more extensive
objections hereafter. . . . â¢ . â¢ â 
The opposition in Scotland is directed mainly
to imports of American beef. Our Consul at Edin
' burgh reports that at a recent meeting'of the directors,
of the Scottish Chamber of Agriculture a resolution
was adopted asking the Town Council of the city to
take steps to check or regulate the sale of foreign
meat brought from Glasgow. It appears that Scot
tish butchers and co-operative stores can obtain
American beef at 9 cents a pound, which is equally as
good as the home beef for which they have to pay 12
cents. There is a greatprotit therefore for the dealer in
handling the American product, and the local farmer
is in danger of losing his home market and with it
his industry.
It is to be noted that the canny Scots do not ask
Parliament for protectidn by a tariff, duty on im
ported beef, but seek it through the medium of
municipal regulations. The same plan is practiced
in Germany to escape the competition not . only of
our meats, but of our fruits. Thus in this volume of
reports there is a statement from Berlin that the
American Embassador, Mr. White, obtained a modi
fication of the recent decree of the Imperial Council
forbidding the importation of American fruit, and
that by this modification all dried fruit had been re
leased from the restrictions of the decree. â 
This report is essentially the same as that given
to the public by telegraph at the time the affair oc
curred. It appears, however, from the report of our.
Consul at Stuttgart that a municipal regulation has
been adopted in that city which forbids the sale of
dried fruit which contains traces of zinc, and gives
notice that dried fruit of American origin has been
found to be especially marked with such traces.
There are, it is evident, more ways than one by
which European producers can get rid of American
competition without involving their Governments
in a tariff war, and it remains to be seen what our
Government can do in the way of retaliation to
remedy the wrong.
Already it is said to be dangerous for Americans
in Havana. There are Spanish in the United States
in large number, but no peril threatens them. There
is a difference between civilization and the lack of it,
which difference this circumstance illustrates.
In defending his daughter's honor a citizen recently
shot five times at the villain in the case and never
touched him. If the necessity for. continuing the
brave defense of honor continue, it would be a good
idea for the father to arm himself with a club.
It is strange that the gamblers of Sacramento per
mit the police to remain in the city. However, the
police do not seem to have enough of a pull to se
riously promote public morals or interfere with the
game.
Registrar Biggy announces that he intends to run
his office on business principles. Perhaps this is all
right. But where has he found a precedent?
To have a Congress on his hands is a mere nothing
to Tom Reed. But that same Congress may tread
on his corns before he is through with it.
SfiN MATEO AND THE BOULEVARD.
MENLO PARK, April 1. 189*.
To the Editor of The Call-Sir: There has been
circulated in the County of San Mateo an address
purporting to be approved by a committee of.citi
zens of that county, formed to investigate a report
made by the County Surveyor and this commission
upon the proposition to issue $310,000 in bonds to
construct certain highways in said county.
As said circular is so misleading and contains
so many erroneous statements we believe it our duty
to the people of San Mateo County to answer same
through the public press. Those members of this
committee we have had the pleasure of meeting
namely, Henry W. Brown of Colma, who presided at
our meeting at that place; George C. Ross of Bel
mont who has written articles for the press of this
county in favor of the bond issue; Alex Moore of,
Pescadero who publicly stated at our meeting on the
30th ult that, having had the subject properly pre
sented to him. he was heartily in favor thereof and
would immediately go among his neighbors and ad
vocate the proposition; Percy W. Selby, who invited
us to the county and has been in accord with the
movement from its inceptionâ all deny giving their
approval to this report.
Through information received from other sources
we are informed that other members of this commit
tee do not approve the report signed by John T.
Doyle C. R. Splivalo and George H. Rice. We are
informed that -Mr. Rice did not sign the report, al
though his name is appended thereto.
We desire to say that this committee has re
fused to meet the Department of Highways before
making their report, although requested so to do by
some members of said committee. In the circular
referred to an estimate is made by the sub-commit
tee, Messrs. John T. Doyle, C. R. Splivalo and George
H. Rice, giving their views by items upon the cost
of constructing said highways, as follows:
Co*t of road per mile, eastern branchâ 2933 yards
of broken rock dumped on road at $3, $8800.
Coast road, mountain partâ 39,lll yards of exca
vation at 20 cents, $7822; 1760 yards broken rocÃ,
$5280; per mile, $13,102.
Coast road, level partâ l76o yards broken rock at
$3, $5280; grading to receive same, $220; per mile,
$5500.
Twenty-eight miles at $8800. $246,400; 35 miles at
$13,102, $458,570; 30 miles at $5500, $165,000; total of
these items, $869,970.
With regard to the cost of broken stone laid on
the road on the "east branch" we desire to say that
not one pound of it will cost more than $1 50 per cu
bic yard and much of it not more than 50 cents; that
we can contract to have all of this rock brought from
Folsc-m Prison rock-crusher to any point on the rail
road along the east branch fur $i 71 per cubic yard.
But this is not necessary, as San Mateo County will
supply rock, for this purpose at a much less cost. As
to rock for the coast road this department does not
propose in its report to rock said road except where
the material is easily obtainable.
The most glaring, false statement In this report
is in placing the cost of the moving of the earth at
20 cents rÂ»pr cubic yard. There is very little of this
country that cannot be plowed with a common road
plow, and any contractor knows that material that
can be plowed can be moved with scrapers. If the
statement made in this circular is true, namely, that
it will cost 20 cents to move the earth, then, according
to all experience, four horses and one man will move
not less than seventy cubic yards per day, which
would mean $14 per day for a team, scraper and
man. We leave our readers to infer the absurdity
of the proposition.
These gentlemen, who have constituted themselves
civil engineers, had better make some estimates for
earth work, for railroads or private parties, and gee
how long the title of civil engineer will remain after
their names.
In justice to ourselves we desire to point to these
glaring errors in order that the people may judge for
themselves. We can only infer that this report, as
it is named, has been framed by a mind totally igno
rant of the subject, and should receive no credence
at the hands of the voters of San Mateo County.
Very respectfully,
MARSDEN MANSON,
J. R. PRICE,
W. L. ASHE,
Department of Highways Commissioners.
SPECIAL FEATURES
IN
THE SUNDAY CALL.
SUPPOSE war should be. declared next week. What about the men
who will lead the- American army? What about, the men who will do
the tramping and the fighting? .
READ NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL,
And find out. Incidentally you will also learn something of the very
queer powders the army and navy use nowadays. The old duck-shooting
powder was a very dangerous explosive to touch a match to. Read about the
new powders that you can burn like punk, and yet their explosive effects are
tremendous. â  ' ; : ..'â â ':
The telegraph brings you messages thousands of miles in a few short
minutes, and the phonograph carries your voice as swiftly, but what do you
think of a new invention that will convey pictures as quickly? Fancy sitting
in a theater in San Francisco and seeing a picture thrown on a screen that
is a fac-simile of one. on exhibition in Paris at the same time. That is ex
actly what ,the inventor promises to do. His experiments have reached the
point where experts do not question his success. How he transmits the pic
tures and the big scale on which the work is being pushed is fully described in
- NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL.
That greatest mechanical genius of the century, Thomas A. Edison, con
tributes a masterly article on "How to Succeed as an Inventor." Read It if
you want to learn of the great problems he has grappled with, and how he
delved through almost insurmountable obstacles till he fairly compelled suc
cess. His story is a great lesson to those whose hearts fail them when it is
simply a case of "try, try again." .. :
Spain has played some ingenious tricks on the Americans during the past
half-dozen, decades, but if you want to learn how some of her shrewd traders
used the stars and stripes to earn tremendous profits in the slave business
READ NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL.
Very recently an Eastern scientist proved that he could graft butterflies,
beetles, bees and other insects, and raise hybrids that would startle Dame
Nature herself. Living beetles with two bodies and butterflies with half a
dozen wings were turned out by this genius as fast as he could wax them to
gether. A. California genius has accomplished something just as wonderful
in the vegetable line. He can grow rou sweet potatoes at one end of a vine
and sweet peas at the other. The other marvels he can accomplish in this
line are told in detail \ .
IN NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL.
Every one knows the value and beauty of the plumes of the egret and
heron. A man has Just returned from Central America who has laid
up a snug fortune hunting them. Duck shooting, quail shooting or any other
kind of bird shooting is gentle, cheerful work compared with egret shooting,
according to his story, but the profits are great if you can capture the plumes.
Then, again, the adventures the hunter experiences in the semi-tropical coun
tries rival anything in the Klondike. Read all about them
IN NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL.
These are only a few of the good things you will find in the columns. If
you want to get them in a bunch, all capitally illustrated, together with the
best and "brightest news of the day,
READ NEXT SUNDAY'S CALL.

Because a man |
happens to be j
fond of society it |
does not follow
that he must
necessarily be a
milk-sop. Many \
of the beaus who j
000000000
Â° PREFERRED
o TO DINE AT
O HOME.
o
000000000
lead cotillions and play the exquisite at j
afternoon teas have been record-holders
In their college days and carry, under
the soft texture of broadcloth and fine
linen, muscles that would be the adml
mtlon of an audience at a prizefight.
Many of these young fellows still keep
up their interest in athletics, and some
of them, who have the opportunity and
means, maintain regular gymnasiums at j
their homes, which are often a source of â 
greater pleasure to the host than to the j
visitor.
The other day a gentleman, who lives at
a prominent down-town hotel, got into a
!3utter-street car and there met the sister
of a friend who has the reputation of be- j
ing one of the best and most enthusiastic !
athletes ever turned out by a large east- >
crn college which is noted for its devo- ]
tion to all sorts of legitimate sport. The
gentleman took a seat next to the young
lady and, after a few preliminary re
marks, said: "How is Will getting along
With that gymnasium he was to construct i
in the house?" "Oh. it is finished and he i
is simply delighted with it, but mamma
and I don't like it at all. You see, it is
in the cellar directly under the sitting
room, and when Will takes his friends
down there after dinner we can hear them
strike against the brick wall and some
times we can even hear their groans. It ;
is lots of fun for Will, but it is not so ;
nice for us, particularly if we are enter- ;
taining any one. It is not as bad as It
was, however, because he don't seem to :
have as many friends come to dinner as
he used to."

APRIL.
I come, like a hope to a gloomy breast.
With comforting smiles, and tears
Of sympathy for the earth's unrest;
And news that summer nears.
For the feet of the young year every day
Patter and patter and patter away.
I thrill the world with a strange delight;
The birds sing out with a will,
And the herb-lorn lea is swift bedight â¢ . '
With the cowslip and daffodil;
While the rain for an hour or two every day
Patters and patters and patters away.
I sing of love, and my strains console
The wish of the wak'nlng mind,
And their echoes roll from soul to soul,
And grow on my murmiirous wind;
And hearts with a true love every day
Patter and patter n 1 ' patter away.
-BERNARD MALCOM RAMSAY in the April
Pall Mall Magazine.

KNIGHTS FERRY, Cal., MaTch 27.
To the Editor of The Callâ Dear Sir: I
wish to make the following statement
in regard to the article on hydrophobia
in California, which appeared in the Ex
aminer of the 20th: Willie Willis was
never bitten by any dog at Knights
Ferry, where he has resided nearly two
years. Dr. F. P. Ciarke, to whom he was

two other prominent specialists of that

were no symptoms of hydrophobia. Dr.

W, "W. Seaman of Los Angeles, Hon.

Jr.: were appointed V>y the State Board

loguer and Janitor, respectively.
The board, which is composed of F.

Auburn, Df.' Thomas S. Hint of San
Juan, Mr. Lemmon of Santa Rosa and
]'.. \V. Lee of Los Angeles, went into

acted business until a little after mid
night.
Miss Green, who has been acting as
Aasistant Librarian at a salary of $1800
per annum, will lose her .position, as
will also J. M. CJiilis and Mr. Craven,
\vl,.. was earning- $100 a month as jan
itor. The board decided to retain tem
porarily Mrs. Neal and Mrs. Hopkins
as assistant cataloguers. The present
Janitress, who is earning $30 a month,
and an assistant law clerk, who is re
ceiving $."0 per month, will also be tem
porarily retained.
The board found that there had not
been an inventory taken of the library
In the past eight years, and as the law
requires one of every department steps
will be immediately taken. It requires
several months' labor, as there are
nearly 108,000 volumes.
Tin- fallowing resolution was adopted
without much discussion:
Whereas, This l>oard aftT a careful in
v< titration of th<' Btate Library with tho
view of ascertaining whether it is being
conducted in an economical manner, finds
that the number of trustees employed in

actually required, and that the number
â¢ reduced from nine to .six, thereby
â¢-- to the Btatp actually in salaries
15200, without in the least impairing the
usefulness of the library; therefore be it
Resolved, That It is the sense of this
board that in addition to the L.orarian
tho following designated employes are
â  ary fur an adequate and economic
administration of the State Library:
Chief deputy, $ir>o p<-r monih; two d<p

â¢'â ;/ tfHA^ AWFUL TEMBLOR.
Rabbi Voorsanger Speaks of It in a
.' : ; . Sermon and Points Some '.-'
â '. â¢â¢;'.'.' '. ." â  -Truths. â¢.
In his sermon on "Religious Suggestions
. From Nature," last evening. Rabbi Voor
| sanger at the outset spoke oh the temblor'
experienced throughout the State on last
â Wednesday night. : lie said: ."I dare say
that if you felt as I did that" night you
were considerably shaken. I plead guilty
to having .been/quite alarmed. Yet I am
not an exception' to the. general rule of
humanity- Man . begins to realize how
helpless he is when a cataclysm, bursts
over the community. We .are unable to
protest, and it teaches, us that .we are
' part of . nature;". '.'â¢ .
The speaker then drew a strong picture
j of the disaster of Souda.'when the. Black
Sea leaped over the land and engulfed
50,000 souls, and :of the Baltic navigator,
who- believes that when he sails the deep
j he can look into the. transparent. waters
: and see the spires of some old city which
I had been , engulfed by the f elements -of
S nature. He continued: " . â¢â¢' " : â¢
"Now, -I.- have n6 doubt there was. quite
; a number of u'sWhb began to realize that
if the' earthquake' had continued but a
few. moments longer we would, have had
what Is '.called .Doomsday. We felt that
the- strength in our. right arm would-be
' of no .avail when the- fortified structures
â of the city shook ; like- an aspen leaf. It
ought to offer us a. lesson iii our calm mo
ment's, when. we. are not buffeted by ter
ror;', when we are hot in fear of a sudden
calamity;, we ought to realize that. we are
a part of mother nature. It is probable.
. that it is just in; such moments vre realize
â¢ our absolute' helplessness and our de
pendency, on. a higher power and begin
! to feel like a flash of -.lightning that awful
.cause/and effect- which conic . from the
â¢Almighty; ''1 dare say- that in that one
moment everybody believed in God,' said,
1 a man to me the next day, but, said 1 to
him, 'Had you. said that in reverence and
piety,- -. instead â¢ of .sarcastic irreverence,
you. would have: told the truth.'' "
The speaker then went on and spoke of
I the approaching "Passover season, and in
. hi a allusions to' ft he spoke in a poetic,
strain, and was listened to with great in
terest.; :â¢â¢â¢â¢â¢" - ".-. ;;";s>;n-

The Ceremony of Blessing the Palms
Will Be Observed To-Morrow
Morning. . .
Palm Sunday will be solemnly ob
served In the 'churches' throughout .ac
city to-morrow, and will mark the com
mencement of holy week, the most sacred
feast in the Catholic church.
T!:. ceremony of blessing and distrib
uting the palms and olive branches will
be h.-hl at St. Francis' Church at 11 '
o'clock in tne iriorr.lr.g. The reading of !
the passion will take the place of a ser- :
mpn, and will be read from the pulpit
Immediately after the consecration of the
palm.
In the evening; at 7:30 o'clock the Rev. |
T. Caraher will deliver a sermon on the
subject of "The Via Dolorosu, or Tracing I
t^e IMood-sfained Steps of the Savior."
On Monday and Thursday evenings the j
X v. T. Caraher will preach on the sub- :
Ject of "The Last Supper."
On Friday evening the discourse will be i
delivered by the Rev. J. Cullen of tne
Sacred Heart Church on the subject of '
"The Passion."
Special holy week services will be held â 
at the Pauliet Church (St. Mary's), com- i
mencing to-morrow morning and con- j
tinuing until Easter.
The Rev. Father Younan. C. S. P., of i
New York will deliver a course of ser
mons on the passion during the entire !
week. A lecture by the same preacher
will also he delivered to-morrow evening '
at the Seamen's Institute at 9 Mission j
sireit. All sailors are cordially invited
to attend.

THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1898.
great art, so far above his previous productions that it marks, it is to
be hoped, the beginning of an epoch in his career, and is clearly worthy
of remark as the possible bounding line of such a period.
An idea of its composition may be had from the accompanying draw-
Ing.;
in handling it is not as firm and sure as might be and there is a
fiddling over detail that is not in strict harmony with the general repose
of the work. But these are slight defects which should disappear with the
confidence that comes with public approval and more work in the same
vein. As' it stands it is poetic in the extreme and is a good picture to
live with: There is a suggestion of Corot and : suggestion of A. P. Rider,
the old American artist who rarely exhibits, but always sells to the in
ner circle of connoisseurs and amateurs. At the same time It is indi
vidual enough not to hir.. of undue influence of the work of any other
artist. Mr. Breuer's picture work will be watched with much interest in
the hope that there will be no falling off from the pace he has set for
himself in "Early Morning."

AT TWO PARKS
Both Oakland and San
Jose Teams to
Contest.
Joe Corbett Will Pitch at Cen
tral Park for the
Athenians.
Free Cars to .Bo Run From Eighth
and Market Streets to Recrea
tion Park.
The San Joee and Oakland teams of
I the California League will go against
each other this afternoon at Recreation
Park. ' Both teams have exhibited here,
San Jose on opening day and Oakland
last Sunday, and they are very evenly
I matched. There has been considerable
j good-natured bantering between Man-
I agers McGlynn and Ewing as to which
would get together the strongest team,
and the players have caught the spirit
of rivalry.
â¢The Market-street Railway Company
has promised â¢ to run free cars from
Eighth and Market streets to Recrea
tion Park, beginning to-day and every
i day that league games are played until
the road is converted into an electric
line. Several two-horse cars will be
i put on and passengers carried to and
i from the grounds without charge.

Reorganized San Jose Team to Meet
the Oakland^ and Joe Corbett
TO- Day.
The reorganized San Jose baseball
team of the Pacific State League will
make its first appearance at Central
Park this afternoon in a game against
the Oaklands. The San Jose team in
cludes all the best talent of last sea
: son's Garden City aggregation, to
! gether with McCarthy, Hanlon and
Hanley of the old Fresno Club.
The Oaklands were defeated by the
i San Jose team last Sunday, but dur
ing the week Manager Coffroth's club
has been strengthened by the addition
[ of Joe Corbett of the Baltimore Na
tional League Club, and Henry Krug,
the crack all-round player of the de
funct pennant winners of last year.
The San Jose and Olympic teams will
play at Central Park on Sunday after
noon. The feature of the game will
be the appearance of James J. Corbutt,
the actor-pugilist, in the role of rirfct
baseman, a position for .which Ms ser
vices were much sought after by man
agers of National League clubs. HÂ«
will wear the uniform of the Olympics.

BOTH ARMS BROKEN.
John Cassidy, Aged 13 Years, Meets
With a Serious Accident.
John Cassidy, aged 13 years, living at
1310 Turk street, while flying- a kite from
the roof of his home yesterday afternoon,
lost his balance and fell to the ground
a distance of twenty-five feet. His cries'
attracted the attention of his mother,
who had him conveyed to the Receiving
Hospital.
An examination by Police Surgeon Weil
; showed that both his arms were broken
by the fall After the injured members
were set the unfortunate boy was re
moved to his home.

CRASHED INTO A WAGON.
An Italian Injured in an Electric Car
Collision.
An electric car of the Fourth-street line
crashed into a wagon which was b^lng
| driven by Gabriello Pucciuelli last night,
wrecking the vehicle and injuring the
driver. The accident happened at Fourth
and Townsend streets.
Pueciuelli was thrown under the car,
but fortunately escaped with a deep gash
over the left eye. He wns taken to the
Receiving Hospital, where the wound was
stitched by Dr. James Kearney.

Injured by an Elevator.
Joseph Hussey, living at 1012 Battery
! street, was caught in the elevator of tne
i Pioneer Warehouse at Battery and Fil
bert streets last evening and severely mi
i jured. He was taken to the Harbor Ro
i ceiving Hospital, and his right leg, which
was broken below the knee, was set by
Dr. Hill.
Town Talk.
Town Talk this Aveek shows no effects
from the earthquake shock. It is brighter
and more newsy than ever, and in "Our
Opinion" strikes boldly against several
late political measures. The New York
Journal is called down for its peculiar
idea of honesty, and in the Saunterer
there are stories about various people we
know in society, on the stage or in politi
cal or club life. A storiette from
real life, reports of lectures, dissertation
on Anna Held and press agents, and a
sketch of Mrs. Jeannette Crawford's life,
by Man' Francis, are features of this
number.

THE MUNICIPAL PRISON A FARCE.
1
Rev. W. H. Tubb made rather a startling statement before the <
Congregational Ministers' Club on Monday- morning. The clergyman has '
long been visiting the prisons and hospitals, and his remarks were ; <
based on what he had perceived. "The municipal prison system," he <
said, "is a farce and should be' changed to an acting drama. The so- <
cial evil is stronger than the, law, and recent efforts to abate .it is <
evidence. Sabbath desecration is telling on the church and it is de- <
pleting it." Â«â  ' ;
A paper read before the ministers of the Christian Church also <
caused considerable talk among the clergy. The paper was entitled .<
"The Lord's Day Meeting of the Church." It was read by Rev. P. G. <
Mclver. He declared that the preacher, had as much right to be late <
and as much right to stay away from church as members of the con- <
gregation. He also blames the congregation for ministers preaching Â«
sensational sermons. He said":
"Sensationalism is caused directly by the members of the church. <
You may think this is a serious charge. I consider it so, but do.'
not hesitate to make it. Now let us see if it is right. What is" â¢
the object of sensational sermons? Their real object is- to draw a â¢
crowd. . But why is it necessary to resort to extremes of this kind? â 
The answer is obvious. The average of the church membership feels â¢
no responsibility on this line. The whole week is passed without a â¢
single invitation to a person outside of the church to enter-its doors. [â¢
"This is not all; the members of the church of to r day seem to.be
imbibing the idea that they are at liberty to be away from the Lord's â 
day meetings; that whether the meetings be a failure â¢ or not no re-,
sponsibility rests upon them; that responsibility rests â¢ en
tirely with . the pastor. A great hue and cry is made
to-day about what the pastors and preachers ought and might
do, but let me say that it is wrong. Let me ask who is more; anx
ious for the growth of the church and the spread of Christianity than
they? Who labors harder to build up the cause of Christ than they?
Who makes greater sacrifice in the. interests of humanity .than they?
Who is more regular at the church services than the minister? Who
is any more prompt than he? None. How often does the pastor go into the
pulpit and find at the hour of service many of the members-are late
or do not come at all? This is ail wrong. .The pastor has / just as
much right to be late or absent as any one of the members. \ â¢ â 
"If the church member has a right to go on a picnic or an ex-
cursion on the Lord's day, so has the pastor. If the members have a
right to stay away from the meetings of the church on the Lord's day
to entertain friends or visitors, so has the pastor.. There is no .
ground or excuse on which the members of the church may remain
away from the services on the Lord's day but the paster or preacher
may do the same. If he is expected to be there to preach the mem
bers are expected to be there to hear and take part in all the services
of the church."
SOLDIERS OF
JESUS CHRIST
Father Yorke Defines the
Duties of Standard-
Bearers.
A Rhetorical Simile Draws
Forth Pointed Patriotic
Utterances.
Incidentally Attention Paid to Pew
Rent and Excuses for Not At
tending Church.
Father Yorke held the attention of an
audience that filled St. Mary's Cathedral
to overflowing last evening. This part c
ular evening of the popular priest's mis
sion was devoted to a sermon on the
Latin military phrase, "Vexilla regia pro
teunt" (the standards of the king go
forth), but he managed to branch out and
hit upon a few things of current interest
ere he had finished, and also to convince
his hearers that dropping a nickel or two
in the contribution box on the first day of
the year and on Palm Sunday does not
constitute a true Christian.
In introducing his subject the speaker
referred to the fact that the close of the
season of prayer and meditation is now
drawing near. His hearers were earnestly
exhorted to bear in mind that the true
Christian is a steward of God. created to
do his work and if he fail in this work
he falls short of the standard. But if the
battle prove hard the servant is always
to remember that he is re-enforced by the
strength of the Master, and that with
such re- e nforcement no battle has ever
vet been lost. The church he regarded
as the institution designed to lead the
repentant into the fold, and any means
of salvation outside her jurisdiction would
'"^^[hre^-'he-aaserted. "one means of
