DENIES THE ALLEGATIONS.
George A. McCalvey Believes His
Wife Is Trying a Divorce Suit
Through the Papers.
George A. McCalvey, who is being sued
for divorce by his wife, states that a
story recently published concerning the
reasons for the suit were mlsstatements
In many particulars and furthermore that
the charges made in the . press as stated
by his wife are totally at variance with
the wording of the complaint on file. Mr.
McCalvey said last evening: "It is true
that my wife has filed a suit for divorce,
but she seems to be trying her case in
the newspapers and not depending on the
wording of the complaint. I have known
of mv wife's absence, but. have made no
attempt to discover her whereabouts. As
she states, she paid a visit to Irvington,
but it was throuch my pleadings with
relatives that she was allowed in the
house â  Whi.e there , she was treated as
mm A t f tÂ£ e toffee left the family Was
well pleased and no search was made
for her as has been stated. She has been
ureed into this action by my political
enemies who are fully aware of her
weakened mental condition from the ex
cessive use of drugs. I will be well
pleased when a divorce is granted."
Will Lay the Cornerstone.
The ceremony of laving the corner
stone of the Sncred Heart Church, the
new Catholic edifice now in process of
construction on Eddy street, between
Scott and Devisadero, will be held with
solemn services to-morroy afternoon at
4 o'clock, being presided over by Arch
bishop Rlordan.
A Steamer Broke Loose.
Last evening- an unnamed stern-wheel
steamer owned by Thomas Ackerman
and which was launched for Klondike
trade off Belmer's ways, South San Fran
cisco, last Tuesday, broke loose from her
moorings and drifted about half a mile
toward Hunters Point. Captain .Wilson
of the launch .Amy went to the scene and
soon had the vessel moored at Jogyer
son's fish wharf, from where she will be
removed to-day by the owner of the ves
sel and prepared for her initial trip to
the North. :
A COMPROMISE EFFECTED.
City Lighting Will Be Kept Within
the Appropriation by the
Supervisors.
The electric light company that has the
contract for furnishing lights to the city
agreed yesterday to accept $25,000 a
month for the months of December, 1597,
and January, IS9S, in lieu of the bills they
had presented to the Board of Supervis
ors. Mayor Phelan vetoed the demands
on the ground that they conflicted with
the one-twelfth act, and the matter was
placed in the hands of the committee to
decide how it should be disposed of.
It is probable that there will be a gen
eral cutting down of lights for the next
five months in order that there may not
be a deficit in the Street Light fund. The
matter will rest for final decision with
the Street Lights Committee.
An Attraction for Vacation.
A special vacation ticket has been
issued by the owners of that wonderful
piece of mechanism on Market and Lark
in streets called "Around the World/ as
a special inducement to public school
children to study all the chief points of
interest and centers of attraction on the
surface of the globe. Many of the his
torical pictures and landmarks shown are
representations of many of the sights and
scenes we see here in our city every day.
Considerable interest â  has been man
ifested in the reproduction of the Claus
Spreckels building and many other large
edifices in the city.
The picture of" that artistic bundle, of
steel and stone on Market and Third
streets is twenty feet in height and a
striking reproduction in every respect. In
addition to scenes in San Francisco the
child will bo afforded an opportunity of
making a thorough study of numerous
points of interest from one end of the
world to the other.
Kelso Sentenced.
John Kelso, the contractor, appeared be
fore Judge Low yesterday morning for
sentence upon the charge of battery on
Alexander Moreno, a process server. Th*
Judge sentenced him to pay a fine of $20
with the alternative of ten days in the
County Jail. The fine was paid. At
torney Phillips, who represented Moreno
will now enter suit for damages againsr
Kelso for injuries sustained by his client
which included a fractured rib.
Left a Valuable Estate.
The estate of the late Michael Mc-
Quaide, consisting of real and personal
property, has been appraised at $29,925 90.

LIVELY RACE
BETWEEN TUGS
The Vigilant Outran the
Alert in a Trial of
Speed.
Some Anxiety Over the Non-
Arrival of the Nellie G.
Thurston.
' â  .- :â â¢â¢."' "f' ..'â¢'â ' i
Spoken 700 Miles Southwest of -This j
Port by tire Steam WhÂ»ler
Jeaneuo.
The tugs Vipilnnt a+id Alert: had a trial
of Speed from the sugar refinery, to Fol-.
som stree.t wharf yesterday, and the Vig
ilant won. The Alert, has recently re- !
celved a thorough overhauling and had
a new boiler put in. When Captain Jo
seph F. Trewren of the AVert found that
he wasto bear the Vigilant company,
back from the refinery he determined to ,
try conclusions with the "crack" of the
Blackstack fleet. Captain John Stlovich
was not averse, so. when an. even start
was had the engineers were told, to open I
the engines up. It was blowing hard and ,
a choppy sea was on; but both steamers -|
flew through it. The spray broke clean j
over the pilot houses, but each captain'
held on and for the first mile neither
had the advantage. Then the Vigilant ]
â¢ began to gain inch by inch and when
Folsoin street wharf was abreast she was
three open lengths to the good. The Vig- f
ilant is much the larger and more power
ful boat of the two, so the Alert* though
beaten, was certainly not disgraced.
There, has been a general jnixup on the
schooner Thomas S. Negus, that arrived
here from New York two weeks ago with
a party of gold hunters. . Captain Mc
: Cl.-ure. who brought the' schooner out, has
sold out his interest in. the vessel, and
Captain Errari. is now in command. ThÂ«
gold hunters had to get all. their sup
plies here and they -made their arrange- "
ments with Smith's cash store by which
the latter takes Over the management of
the schooner and the miners get their
supplies. :-. ; :-The Negus is going with the
New Yorkers to Copper River and on her
return to San Francisco she will be ntted
out to carry passengers to St. Michael.
The steamer Zealandia arrived from
Honolulu yesterday with seventy-four
cabin and thirty-nijie steerage passenger*.
She was late in leaving Honolulu, and
owing to heavy head weather she was
unable to make up- the lost tlhre.
The schooner Nellie G, Thurstori. now
out 172 days from New York for SatÂ»
Franftiaco vrlth a party -of nineteen gola
hunters, has been spoken 700 miles south
west of this port by the steam whaler
Jeahette TheJeanette left here for Hon- '
oluiu on March !i, and arrived' there four
teen days later. From. Honolulu the>
news :Of the speaking came by the Zea
landia, so the schoorief must have met
some very heavy 'and adverse weather
to have kept her off port so- long.
The old wooden bark Dominion is a I
very long timeâ loo days-^-out from New
castle, N, S. W. She was spoken on Jan
uary 3, but the position was not given,
bo she should have been along some weeks j
ago. The. Dominion was sent to Aus- i
tralia by T. B. H. .^Thitefaw to be sold.
The- captain found a purchaser, but he
.pocketed, the money and Whitelaw has
neither seen nor heard of him from that
day ..to this. The Dominion was built in
1575 and. is 1214 tons net burden, is owned
toy CoyrHslaw Bros, of Sydney, N. S. W.,
and has. a Cargo of -coal" consigned to J.
J. Moore & Co. ,-i. v'
There .Was nearly a collision between
tbe baj-kentine J. SI. Griffiths and the
pilot-boat Grac.ie S yesterday. The bar- |
kentine came in â  from sea and anchored
near 'the schooner. Soon she began to \
drag arid- the captain on tl c Oracle S had
to' slip, his anchor and maÂ£e sail in order j
. to" avoid a collision. The tug Reliance '
w>s sent â to the rescue and towed the
Griffiths'to a safe anchorage.
The -schooner Edward Parke had to
comic back to p^rt. yesterday. Two days
ago' she sailed for Willapa harbor, but
was caught in a storm outside and lost
her jibbopm. After her repairs have
been, made' she will proceed.
The steamer Walla Walla sailed tor
Puget Sound ports yesterday with over
300 passengers. '. Some of them are going
to- the gold fields, but the majority are
taking advantage of the cut rates over
â¢ the Canadian Pacific Railway.
JUSTICE COOK EXONERATED.
Collector Besecker Circulated False
Stories Concerning His Honor.
In The Call of the 24th of last month
the. statement was. published that Col
lector D. E. Beseeker, thinking he had
not obtained justice in Justice of the
Peace Cook's court, had accused the Jus
tice of heeding a pull.
It was stated \hat Beseeker said in j
open court: "I will get justice from a|
court that knows what justice is. This!
Is the first time that I have noticed a
court where a 'pull' could be exerted,
Buch as is in evidence here to-day. I
thoroughly understand the reasons* why'
such, a decision is rendered/but you may i
be -sure' that I do riot intend to let this 1
matter rtst." .
Justice Cook denies that any such
scene ever occurred in his court. On In
vestigation The Call has learned that the I
Btory. substantially as printed, emanated j
from Beseeker, who told Justice Kerri
gan arid others that he had denounced
Justice. Cook, as stated by The Call. Why
Besecker thus misrepresented the facts
jn the case is not known, but the truth â¢
Is that he did not use any language of the I
character quoted nor did he make any- 1
Incriminating accusations within the
hearing of the court. â¢-: â¢ â  \
Special Musical Service.
At the Church of the Advent, Eleventh
street, near Market, there will be a spe
cial musical service next Sunday morn
ing at.il o'clock, it being Palm Sunday.
Aniorip : other numbers of interest, Gou
nod's Second/Mass to the Orphans will
be sun^ by a. semi-chorus, the first tenor
part hfi rig sustained by five selected boys.
The offertory will be "The Palm
Branches.: sung by Henry Kirke White
Jr. In. the evening, at the regular service
at 7:Ah. the "Story of the Cross" will be
ren^cied foi the last time this yoai- by
Ihe full vested choir of fifty nien and
boys. Both â  services are urder tho per
sonal direction of Hen.-y Kirke White Jr.
The sf-rmcritj kt. both services will be de
livered by the Rev. J. A. Emery, rector
of the .church^ .. ;
.THIS WEEK'S WASP. .
The .Wasp this week is an extraordi
narily â¢.elever/jssuepf that always bright
and Interesting: publication. The . editor
ials, always, vigorous -arid well written,
are on. topics' th'a.t'.ar.e -.attracting general
attention.. The new .charter .Is reviewed
at length, and the Plain- Talk to Public
Characters, addressed this, week to Rail
road Commissioner William M. Hinton. is
well worth roading. The musical criti
cisms, the society side-lights, the person
alities and the theatrical review are some
of the Wasp's departments that are par
ticularly good this week. The ilnancial
column should be read by every specu
lator, and those who are at all interested
In stocks, bonds, grain, etc.. will find
much of value to them in that depart
ment. Besides a surfeit of splendid half
tone engravings the Wasp's colored car
toons this week add to the general at
tractiveness of the paper. The center
cartoon depicting Uncle Sam and Don
Hlspano negotiating peace and at the
same time preparing for war is very well
executed.

Maria Parente, widow of Agostlno

children from their home on Vincent
street, near Green, on February 28 last,
commenced suit yesterday against Mich
ael Tano, who lays claim to the property,
to have the deeds he holds canceled in
court, in addition to paying her $1000 dam
ages. ThÂ» elaJm is made by the widow
that the property is a homestead and that
THE VIGILANT WINS BY THREE LENGTHS.
After a thorough overhauling and having had new boilers put in Captain Trewren of the Alert thought his
vessel was equal to a brush with the Vigilant. The tugs raced from the Sugar Refinery to Folsom-street wharf,
and the showing was a. very creditable one for the Alert, as she is much the smaller boat of the two.
her husband signed the deeds held by
Taho under the mistaken belief that he
was signing papers making it a home
stead. The case was tried several months
ago before Judge Hebbard, and he gave
judgment in. favor of Tano. It was under
that judgment that the ejection took
place. â¢ â  . â¢
DETERMINED ON MURDER.
Daniel O'Connor Arrested for Threat
. . ening to Kill His Wife.
Daniel O'Connor, a corn doctor, was
arrested yesterday on a warrant charg
ing him with threats to kill. The com
plaining: witness is his wife, Mary O'Con
nor, who lives at 1516 Howard street.
O'Connor and his wife have been living
apart for- some years. About four months
ago, while she was living on Erie street
with her daughter, O'Connor forced hia
way into the house and attempted to kill
her by stabbing her with a knife. He
was arrested, but after she recovered she
refused to prosecute him for the sake of
her daughter and O'Connor promised
Judge Joachimsen that he would leave
the city and never molest his wife again.
He left the city, but returned again a
day or two ago and Thursday night he
went to his wife's house with an ax and
attempted to kill her. She fled and there
by saved her life.
â  m â 
Suspected of Stealing.
J. M. Matthew was arrested yesterday
afternoon on Geary strict by Policeman
George Collins and locked up in the
"tanks" at. the City Prison. Matthew had
in his possession a piece of dress goods
which he could not satisfactorily account
for and the police believe it has been
stolen.

Wants to Become a Sole Trader.
Mrs. Marj' Junker filed a petition in the
County Clerk's office yesterday asking to
become a sole trader. She is anxious to
engage in business to earn a livelihood for
herself and husband, Louis Junker, who
has been an Invalid for over a year and
unable to work.
JOSEPH D. GRANT, ART PATRON.
The New President of the San Francisco
Art Association.
JOSEPH D. GRANT has been chosen to preside over the destinies of
the San Francisco Art Association for the ensuing year, and a better
selection could not have been made. The board of directors, consist-
Ing of Messrs. J. D. Grant, James D. Phelan, L. P. Latimer, Edward
Bosqui, H. G. Platt. George Whittell, James W. Byrne. Arthur Rodg
ers. Henry Heyman, Irving M. Scott and William G. Stafford, elected last
Tuesday, met at the Hopkins Art Institute yesterday and selected the fol
lowing officers: Joseph D. Grant, preside.it; Edward Bosqui, first vice-pres
ident; L. P. Latimer, second vice-president; William G. Stafford, secretary;
George Whittell, treasurer.
Mr. Grant has been a member of the association since Its organization
and has labored hard for its success. He has served twice on the board
of directors and his selection as president is only well-merited recognition
of his services in behalf of art and artists.
A man of wealth and always a liberal patron of art, Mr. Grant In his
new position will work with Increased interest for -he advancement of art
and the welfare of the association. His advancement will be hailed with de
light by the fraternity E,r he has always been ready to extend a helping
hand to struggling artists. Mr. Grant has spent much time in the art cen
ters of Ei -ope and is regarded as ojie of the best critics in this country.
THE SA^. FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1898.
OFFICERS ARE
BEING SHIELDED
Witnesses in the Haynes Ex
amination Have Faulty
Memories.
Cannot Tell How the Policemen Acted
When Lieutenant Burke Met
His Death.
Judge Conlan's courtroom was again
crowded yesterday afternoon with curious
spectators, who stretched their necks to
get a view of the eccentric murderer of
Lieutenant .ourke. The testimony elicited
dtiring the hearing was similar to that
already published, and the constant ques
tioning of ..ue attorneys for the defense
and prosecution over beaten paths became
wearying to the court and listeners. At
one stage Judge Conlan's feelings could
not be restrained, an. he pettishly said:
"Let this witness go, for God's sake; he
has answered that time and asrain."
Chief Lees was an Interested listener to
the proceedings, and would often prompt
Prosecuting Attorney Mogan for the pur
pose of en.ightening himself on the con
duct of his officers during the exciting
scenes surrounding the brave lieutenant's ;
death.
Witnesses examined were averse to tell
ing what the arresting officers did by
evasively answering that they did not see
them, their attention being centered on
Burke and Haynes.
Attorneys Wilson and Sweeney's erforts
were mainly directed toward getting an
admission from the witnesses .at
Burkf's menacing front was the reason
why Haynes shot, but without success.
They also attempted 10 show by the wit
nesses that Haynes was often teased,
hooted at, stoned and was a prey for
petty thieves in me neighborhood, ail of
which they denied or said that they had
not heard of such stories.
Peter Rooney, the first witness ca-.ed,
said he was a neighbor of the defendant;
that on the day of the shooting he saw
Haynes from 8:30 o'clock up to the time
it occurred, he heard shots and then saw
Burke stagger back along Peralta avenue
to Montcalm and fall; that about a
minute after Burke raised himself up on
his elbow and fired a shot toward Haynes'
cabin. Wilkinson, Merchant. Marlowe and
Kennedy were stationed on the northwest
corner of Peralta avenue, but when the
shots were fired they shifted around. He
saw Marlowe firing at Haynes when he
came out to deuver the other shots at the
lieutenant and pick up his pistol, Dut
could not see the others, and did not know
where they went; t.*at after Burke lay
on the ground ten minutes Patrol-Wagon
Driver Cashel pulled him down the hill,
assisted by Jonnny -icGrath. He saw
them put the wounded officer in a
stretcher and then lift him into the pa
trol-wagon.
On cross-examination, he said he had
lived in the neighborhood seven years, and
knew Haynes since then. Attorney
Sweeney led him over his testimony but
beyond tangling him up on one or two
things, nothing o. importance was
elicited
John T. Graham, a grocer, residing at
Precita and Alabama streets, told how
Hopkins came into his store and com
plained of Haynes and of his telephoning
to the Seventeenth-street station, and of
Kennedy and Wilson coming out on horse
back. How Wilkinson returned to the
patrol box and telephoned for advice and
of Burkes coming a short while after.
The next he saw of the lieutenant was
when he was on the patrol-wagon on his
way to the hospital. On cross-examina
tion, he said he had known the defendant
eignteen or twenty years. He denied that
he had ever seen boys throw stones at
the defendant or that Haynes had ever
com-iained to him of his treatment. He
also denied ...at Haynes ever came down
to his place to recover stolen property.
Rooney was recalled and a.Â«ked whether
the boys had ever stoned Haynes 1 cabin,
but said he did not know of his own
knowledge, but heard they dm.
Robert Cole, residing at 3244 garrison
street, was en called. He was nervous
and created some merriment b-<' his man
ner ot testifying. He would place his hat
on his chair and then stand up to answer,
and when told to sit down would sit on
his derby. Prosecuting Attorney Moean
was kept busy trying to prevent his wit
ness from destroying his headgear.
He testified mat he worked in the Green
\ alley livery stable as harness-cleaner
from 6 o'clock in the evening till that hour
next morning; that was his habit to eat
breakfast and ta-.e a stroll around the
neighborhood ...ore going to bed; tnat
his attention was attracted by seeing two
officers on horseback moving toward
Haynes place, and that he starteu up
that way, and met Mr. Doody, a neighbor
In company with him he reached a place
of vantage and awaited develonments
He then went over the old ground, nar
rating ti.e events that led up to the shoot
ing.
He told of his standing 250 feet away
and listening to i urke's command to give
in and Haynes* excited replies; that
Burke had his right hand in his pocket
and with his left hand threw back his
coat, disclosing his badge of office; that
Haynes warned him away and then rais
ing his pistol, lire,., that the lieutenant
drew his gun the same instant, when
Haynes again shot; that Burke staggered
back and fired again. He then told ho :
Haynes had left his cabin and, stooping
over t'ae lieutenant, picked up something
and nred a few more shots. A^tornev
Sweeney succeeded in his cross-examina
tion in bewildering the witne-s unul he
did not know whether he saw the shoot
ing or whether was a dream. He made
all kinds of contradictory statements and
was in a bad plight until rescued by the
court.
Havnes sat throughout the afternoon
blinking his eyes and listening intently
to what was being: said. He wouK confer
with his attorieys, and at one point he
raised a piping voice and asked the wit
ness where he was standing. He was
quieted by nis counsel, and then laDsed
into a stoicliKe attitude during the re
mainder of ...e session. The case was con
tinued until L o'clock to-day, when fur
ther testimony will c heard.
ATTORNEYS ONLY CAN ACT.
Clients Cannot Settle â  Their Cases
Without Their Representatives.
The Supreme Court has handed down a I
decision which will cause some rejoicing !
among the attorneys of the State, for
it establishes as law that when a man
places his case in the hands of a law
yer he has no right to settle the difficulty
oat of court without the knowledge and
consent of his attorney. M. G. Wyllie
brought an action against the Sierra Gold
Company to recover money. An amended
complaint was filed on November 4, !
1896. To this a general demurrer was i
filed by the defendant, which was
overruled and ten days allowed to !
answer. No answer having been !
filed on December 4, the clerk of the !
court, upon application of the attorney '
for the plaintiff, was directed to enter a
judgment in default for the amount. On
the same day. but a little later, the de
fendant filed a notice of a motion to set
aside the judgment and permit the de
fendant to answer.
He gave as his reason that he had
been taken by surprise, in this, that the ;
"plaintiff" had extended the time to an-
Bwer to December S, and he produced i
affidavits to show that In the interim the !
two parties to the action had been con
sideling a compromise by means of let- j
ters and conversations. On hearing, his
petition was denied by the lower court,
from which ruling he appealed. The Su
preme Court holds that the party losing j
by this failure to answer has no redress, j
for "his attorney should have known bet- \
ter than to allow the matter to go by \
the board in such a way. and says: I
"When a party appears and is represent- I
ed by an attorney of record he cannot !
himself assume control of the case, and j
if he signs a stipulation dismissing the
action or extending the time for any pur- ;
pose, the stimulation will have no ef- '
feet and will be disregarded by the ;
court."
Special German Gathering.
A special meeting in the interest of the
German Young Men's Christian Associa
tion will be held Sunday afternoon at 3
o'clock In the German Lecture Hall, cor
ner Ellis and Mason streets, this city.
Several speakers will address the meet
ing, among whom are the following gen
tlemen: Rev. F. Bonn, Secretary Homer,
J. G. Thomas nnd others. All persons in
terested in this worthy institution for
the welfare of the German-speaking
young men are cordially invited to at
tend.
A New Corporation.
H. A. Moss. George H. L. Beckedorff,
Alfred W. Fee, Andrew A. Anderson and ,
James W. Benchley have filed articles of i
incorporation of Moss & Co. The corpor
ation will engage in a general wholesale I
and retail business in grain.

LOST HIS LOVE
AND HIS CASH
Why Alonzo Mclver Be
gan Suit in the Jus
tice Court.
Woman He Adored Took His
Coin and Then Married
Another.
Justice Groezinger Decides for the
Defendant After Reading
Some Letters.
"Love'a labor and money lost" was the
burden of a tale of woe that was told in
Justice of the Peace Groezinger's court
yesterday.
Alonzo Mclver was suing Frank P.
Howard and Emelie Howard for $160,
money advanced to the fair defendant in
the action when she was yet a single
woman. Mclver, according to' his own
admissions on the stand, was desperately
in love with the fair Emelie, and was at
the time the money was alleged to have
been advanced the possessor of consid
erable coin, xie was a habitue of the
race track and a plunger In a way.
She who afterward became Mrs. How
ard accepted his presents and attentions,
the former including numerous sums of
money that were itemized in the bill of
particulars.
While Emelie and Alonzo were friends,
according to the testimony, she was ac
customed to draw on him for whatever
funds she needed. These items began
along about March, 1896, and the first sum
that Mclver alleged to be due him was
$5 which Mclver said was advanced to
enable the lady of his affections to join
the French Benevolent Society. Then
came an item that reads as follows:
Cash, July 10, 18%. when F. P. Howard
broke his leg, $10.
F. P. Howard Is the party defendant.
About this time Mclver's Inamorata de
cided to go East, and the bill of particu
lars says that Mclver advanced $40 for a
second-class ticket tnat was to carry her
there.
When Mrs. Howard's father needed
some shirts and other little necessities
Mclver's complaint says that he paid for
them at a well-known haberdasher's on
Market street, 'j. hen there was $20 cash
advanced when the lady in the case was
out of funds.
In September, 1596, the prospective Mrs.
Mclver was in Wellington, Kan., and
wanted to return to. San Francisco. The
plaintiff's itemized account says that he
advanced her $50 for that purpose. Al
together he claims that he "loaned" the
lady $150.
And yet when she came bacK from the
East she united her life and fortunes
with Howard, who, because he is her
husband, is made a party defendant In
the case. Mclver alleged that he had
parted with his coin because the fair
Emelie had requested the money in the
nature of loans. Mrs. Howard said that
the money was presented to her in the
nature of tokens of Mclver's affections.
To prove that Mclver was head over
heels in love with her Mrs. Howard pro
duced Mrs. George W. Parsons as a wit
ness in her behalf. The witness, a dash
ing blonde, whose husband works with
Howard as a telegraph operator in the
office of a morning dally, and who was
formerly Mrs. Lulu Peel, testified that
Mclver had escorted her home on more
than one occasion, and while on these
pleasant journeys had poured forth his
tale of love for the lovely Emelie. â 
"What was your condition as to sobri
ety while with Mclver?" asked the at
torney for the plaintiff when Mrs. Par
sons finished her story. , The lawyer's in
tention was apparently to show that
there had been a jolly luue time. Jus
tice Groezinger ruled out the question,
however, and the indignant Mrs. Parsons
was not permitted to answer.
To clinch its case the defense Intro
duced a large number of .etters written
by Mclver to the lady who jilted him,
in which he used every endearing name
known to lovers and spelled "pet" "peat."
He told her there was nothing he would
not do for her; that his heart, his hand
and his fortune were at her feet, and
that, though she did not answer his let
ters as regularly as he wished, he- loved
her still.
After reading these endearing epistles
Justice Groezinger decided that the sums
advanced could not have been exactly in
the nature of loans and gave judgment
against Mclver.
SCHOOL DIRECTORS CENSURED.
West of Castro Street Improvement
Club Speaks Its Mind on the
School Question.
Had any or all of the Board of Educa
tion been spectators of the West of Cas
tro Street Improvement Club last night
they would have felt the atmosphere very
warm, notwithstanding the cold and chil
ly wind that was blowing on the outside.
Immediately after the club was called
to order by Chairman W. J. Nixon, sev
eral members were falling over each
other to obtain the floor in order to have
a whack at the "shuffling eight," for the
manner in which the children of Noe Val
ley are treated as regards school accom
modation.
Major B. McKinne obtained the floor
and read an article from The Call of yes
ADVERTISEMENTS.
THEY WANT TO TELL
These Grateful Women Who Have
Been Helped by Mrs. Pinkham.
Women who have suffered severely
and been relieved of their ills by Mrs.
Pinkham's advice and medicine are
constantly urging publication of their
statements for the benefit of other wo-
men. Here are two such letters:
Mrs. Lizzie Beverly, 258 Merrimac
St., Lowell, Mass., writes:
" It affords me great pleasure to tell
all suffering women of the benefit I have
received from taking Lydia E. Pink-
ham's Vegetable Compound. I can hard-
ly find words to express my gratitude for
what she has done for me. My trouble
was ulceration of the womb. I was un-
der the doctor's care. Upon examina-
tion he found fifteen very large ulcers,
but he failed to do me good. I took sev-
eral bottles of Lydia E-. Pinkhams Vege-
table Compound, also used the Sanative
Wash, and am cured. Mrs. Pinkham's
medicine saved my life, and I would
recommend it to all suffering women."
Mrs. Amos Tbombleay, Ellenburgh
Ctr., N. V.. writes:
*' I took cold at the time my baby
was born, causing me to have milk
legs, and was sick in bed for eight
weeks. Doctors did me no good. I
surely thought I would die. I was al-
so troubled with falling of the womb.
I could not eat, had faint spells as
often as ten times a day. One day a
lady came to see me and told me of the
benefit she had derived from taking
Lydia E. Pinkham's medicine, and ad-
vised me to try it. I did so, and had
taken only half a bottle before I was
able to sit in a chair. After taking
three bottles I could do my own work.
I am now in perfect health. "
terday morning, in which the school ques
tion of Noe Valley was shown to be as
it is.
Major McKinne, in unmeasured terms, j
denounced the Board of Education for its <
! misconduct in not providing school ac-
I commodation for the children of that dis- !
j trict, where, he stated, there were by !
j actual census 400 children without a suit- j
I able place to attend school.
Following these remarks, Chairman
Nixon offered the following resolutions, j
which were unanimously carried:
Whereas The knowledge comes to this club i
that the Board of Education had an ppportu- I
nlty to rent a suitable building at a nominal i
rental to accommodate the 400 school children i
living west of Castro street and thereby bring I
the scattered classrooms now existing under
one roof ; and
Whereas, This should be done as quickly as
possible so as to obviate the necessity of sep- [
arating the small children of one family as ia t
now the case: and
Whereas, The sits mentioned. Hoffman and I
Twenty-fifth streets, is most desirable for lta ]
location from street cars and its ideal sur- '
roundings, being entirely sheltered' Jby trees
with large grounds for play yards; therefore.
be It â â -.-;â 
Resolved, That this club condemns the action
of the Board of Education in nnt having- the '
interest of this district at heart; and be it i
further â  j
Resolved, That the Board of Education be 'â ;
petitioned to reconsider its action at the next
meeting and that the proposed site be obtain- | :
ed at a nominal rental for a school house im- I
mediately in accordance with the wishes df the j
citizens of this district; and be it further ' |
Resolved. That a copy of these resolutions be |
handed the secretary of the Board â  of Educa- f
tion by the president of this club. â  T
The car question, with its creeping gait,
came in for a portion of the evening's- !
consideration. And it was resolved that
the superintendent of the Market-street :
system be requested to restore the. eight
mile schedule to all ears running Into the
Mission. â¢ ...
Short but pointed speeches were made
by Chairman Nixon, F. E.Hackney, Major
F. H. Qualman, James Cotter, T. J. Hune, |
C. E. Osgood, B. F. Johnson and others
on the many questions in which the val
ley has an interest.
F. E. Hackney, C. E. Osgood and B. F.
Johnson were appointed a committee to
review the new charter and report at
the next meeting as to its worth, and
"what will It do for the Mission," if '
adopted.

his discourse, which he announced as
being in two parts, the second of which
is to be given next year, he- proceeded,
saying, in part: "It iÂ» unquestionably
true that singing has great Influence upon
the action of the lungs, for tne increase
of the volume of air which passes into
the lungs when singing is very beneficial.
Professional singers have the highest vi
ta) capacity, ami exhale from 4Odo to 5000
centimeters in one breath. Vocal exer
cises, repeated daily, will provide tor an
increased ventilation of the blood and
lungs, the inner chest becomes enlarged
in. all three ' dimensions, the vertebral
column is stretched .and we instinctively
hold ourselves erect when singing. It also
considerably- influences the circulation,
and the whole process of nutrition in im
proved thereby, more, oxygen is inhaled
and more carbonic acid expired. This in
creases the need of food, and singers
usually, enjoy good appetites and. great
thirst. â ..'.â  . â¢. . . ' â â¢'
"Men of sedentary habits are apt to
suffer from, digestive disturbances, in con
sequence of stagnation of circulation.
Viiis.cah be corrected by vocal exercise,
for. in singing' the' diaphragm causes in
its dowh ward movement a corresponding
change in the aujacent liver, stomach and

PATRIOTIC BED MEN.
Bald Eagle : Tribe Adopts Ringing
Resolutions Regarding Cuba.
At a meeting last Tuesday of Bald
Eagle Tribe. No. 75. Improved Order of
Red Men, the following resolutions wera
unanimously adopted:
vr-hereas. Our oTder Is the direct descendant
of- that patriotic society.; The Sons of Liberty,
which during the war of the Revolution num
bered among its niernbers. many of those heroes
who fought and bted tjiat independence might
be proclaimed, to the American people, and
whereas, the patriotic and liberty-loving peopl*
oÂ£ Cuba are at- present enpagred In a struggle
tor the freedom- of their native Jani. be it
. Resolved.' That we as an organized frater
nal and Hberty-lovlhg bodj\ composed of loyal
American citizens', hereby appeal to our Sena
tors and Representatives in Congress to us 9
their best efforts, for the recognition of the
Cuban republic as a free and independent gov
ernment.: and be tt further
Resolved.' That these resolutions be spread in
full upon the records of this tribe, and a copy
thereof transrnltted- to the Hon. Stephen M.
AVhlte. the Hon. George C, terklns. the Hon.
James G. Maguire and the Hon. E. F. Loud.

For a violation of this law, section 61
of the Penal Code provides as follows:
Every person who willfully violates any
of the provisions of the laws of this State
relating to elections is, unless a different
punishment for such violation is pre
scribed by this code, punishable by a fine
not exceeding $1000 or by Imprisonment in
the State prison not exceeding live years,
or by both.
It Is further claimed that McNeil has
also violated section 19 of the purity of
elections law, which reads as follows:
It shall be unlawful for any person to
I make any gift, loan, promise, offer, pro
ment or agreement, as aforesaid, to.
for nr with any person, in order to Induce
such person to procure, or endeavor to
procure the election of any person â¢ â¢ â¢
.Every perron who commits any of the

prisonment in the State prison for not
Ipss than one year nor more than seven
The words "as aforesaid"' refer to
paragraph 2 of section 19, which reads
as follows:
. To give, offer or promise any office,
place or employment, or to promise to
procure, or endeavor to procure, any of
flee, place or employment.
â It is claimed that McNeil request
Smith's aid to secure his (McNeil's
election where in his letter he says
"You cannot be elected Mayor; it is a
physical impossibility. With your aid
I can be." How that aid can be ex
tended Mr. McNeil explains in the sen
tence which opens this article.
It is but justice to Mr. Smith to stat
that the first knowledge of this lette
was obtained by The Call from a mem
ber of the Charter Club. Mr. Smith
had confided its contents to a number
of his friends in that organization.
When Mr. Smith was asked if he had
received such a letter he replied in the
affirmative, but it was with the great
est reluctance and only after he had
taken counsel with his friends and an
attorney that he consented to allow
the letter to be made public. The
reason he gave fcr permitting this pub
licity was that he and his friends con
t sidered that the letter was one that did
| not concern his interests alone, hut
those of the entire Charter Club ticket
and the welfare of the city of San Jose.
! He had also been advised by the attor
ney whom he consulted that he was un
der neither a moral nor a legal obliga
tion to consider his communication as
. confidential. It related, as was told, to
: public affairs of the most vital interest
| to . San Jose, and virtually sought to
make the recipient an accessory to
what was considered to be a felony. In
tlio course of an interview with Mr.
McNeil ho virtually admitted having
written this letter to Mr. Smith, and
1 showed clearly by his unwarranted
abuse of that gentleman that he has
hoped to impose what appears to be !
ian unfair and unlawful confidence
; upon that gentleman.

ter written to Mr. S. K. Smith, the can
didate of the Charter Club?" asked The

â¢ taining the following words: "If you will
consent lo permit the withdrawal of your
name for the Mayoralty, you can com
mand me and my services for any office,
present or future, within my power."
! "I can't say just now," replied Mr. Mc-
Neil, "whether 1 recognize all the words
' that are on this slip or not. I can give
;.you a detinite answer by comparing them
with a letter I wrote a short time ago
Would you like me to compare this Bli
With my letter?"
"Yes, sir."
The text of this particular part of th
' purity of elections law was handed to Mr
McNeil >or his perusal.
"I see nothing in this section," said Mr
McNeil, "at all applicable to any privat
â¢ letter I may have addressed. I hay

endeavored to seure the withdrawal of
man who cannot be elected ~iayor of San
j Jose. As an earnest of my sincerity, am

welfare of this city, I also wrote severa

New Charter Club, in which I urged th
withdrawal of Mr. Smith, not that I ob
Ject to- the gentleman, but because 1 be
lieve he cannot be elected."
"I><> you claim that those words re
ferred to in your letter were not an offer
to contribute a valuable consideration to
Mr. Smith in consideration of his with
drawing as a nndidate for public of
liee, namely, that of Mayor?"
"I do claim that most emphatically and
I unequivocally. You may Dut it in capl
j tal letters if you wish. I am not now
| engaged in crooked politics."
"Wa.s not that an offer of a valuable
consideration?"
"No, sir."
"Why?"
"Because it was not, and by no stretch
of the imagination can it be construed
as such."
"Was not the offer of an office a valu
able consideration?"
â "I have made no offer of any office, or
any valuable consideration or anything
else to secure anything whatsoever. I am
not now engaged in that line of business.
Moreover, 1 wish to express to you my
supreme contempt for a man aspiring for

ligion is purity, a man who would rue
or ruin this city. I say 1 look with su-i

violate a personal communication ad- i

other's injury. Mr. Smith can have but

, stamp* him a.s one beneath the respect i
i of decent men."
"There is another portion of this purity I
\of elections law that, it Is claimed, is
violated by these words. This is section
19, paragraph 3."

law Mr. McNeil remarked:
That is another section that suits your

article."

THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1898.
ALAMEDA COUNTY NEWS.
THREE LETTERS
STIR SOCIETY
How Young Men Tried
to Insure . Answers
to Invitations.
Misses and Matrons Puzzled at
the Additions to Usual
Forms.
Yet Somehow the Suggestion Seems
to Have Been Generally
Understood.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 1.
Three young society men, who are also
students of the University of California.,
have startled the misses and matrons by
the boldness of their invitations to a lit
tle luncheon that is to be given at their
chapter house to-morrow afternoon. All
kinds of little sensations are continually
cropping up in Oakland society, but the
latest is thought by some to be a huge
j joke and by others to be rather too sug
i gestive.
| To be plain, the three young gentlemen
I have introduced a departure in the
method of Invitation that is unique. The
invitation is issued on light green paper
and is as follows:
<$> â¢ <$>
! NOTICE :
: Blx-Dlx-Chinx Luncheon :
: at :
: D. K. E. Hall, :
; on :
: Saturday, April 2, at 1 O'clock. :
: Consider Yourself Asked. :
! R. 8. V. P.â P. D. Q. !
<Â£â¢ <!>
The innovation is in the last three let
i ters, "P. D. Q.," and when the young
! ladies received their little green notes
there was consternation and inquiry as
i to the meaning of the three capitals: Tho
I luncheon is being given by Fred Blxby,
I Dixwell Davenport and Allen Chlckerlnfc
i and Mesdames Bixby, Davenport and
[ Chlckering are to be chaperones. It has
! long been a grievance in local society that
I the "R. S. V. P." has been neglected and
I a few weeks ago just forty Invited guests
j responded out of 250 Invitations, and there
i was trouble. This neglect has caused
j much trouble to hostesses and every ef
; fort has been made to bring about some
' reform.
The young men at Berkeley undertook
i to emphasize the "R. S. V. P." and so
they added the "P. D. Q." Among the
invited guests are Miss Marietta Havens,
Pauline Fore, Carmen Moore, Ida Belle
| and Bessie Palmer, the Misses Duff, Da*
! venport, Marie Rose Deane and many
' others from the Lakeside district. AVhen
these young ladies received their invita
tions they scanned them very thoroughly
1 and the "P. D. Q." was a veritable con
nundrum for them. Fathers and broth
: ers were asked, but all professed ignor
i ance, and the young ladies are still in
! doubt. The luncheon comes off to-mor
rew and the three young hosts will have
an interesting time explaining away their
! little suggestion to their guests.
The little incident has aroused great in
â  terest. It is generally regarded as a bold
innovation and thf'rc is a desire to know
what may be expected next.
There is one peculiar feature to the al
i legeu ignorance of the young ladies re
| garding the cabalistic signs. It is re
i markable that acceptances were sent in
; with greater speed than for months. As
one of the invited young men guests said,
"Those answers came in in accordance
with the suggestion."
STRUCK BY A
LOCAL TRAIN
A Fatal Accident to Mrs.
Jennette Whiteford Yes
terday.
Walked Upon the Track in a Strong
Wind and Was Hit Without
Warning. *
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 1.
Mrs. Jennette Whiteford, 60 years of
a^e, was struck by the 2:30 train from
the pier this afternoon as she was cross
ing the Seventh street local tracks at
Wood street. The pilot struck the unfor
tunate woman and It is believed that but
one person witnessed the accident.
William Davidson gives the following
account of the affair: "1 saw Mrs. White
ford as she started across the street. She
had her head down against the wind and
evidently did not see nor hear the train
approaching. The engineer did not whis
tfe nor did the bell ring, and no effort
was made to stop the train. In fact
I do not believe that the engineer knew
an accident had happened, for the train
went right along."
Mrs. Whiteford was removed to the Re
ceiving Hospital, where Drs. Stratton and
Milton treated her. Internal injuries
caused bleeding of the ears and mouth
Littlo hope is held by the attendants of
her recovery. She is a sister of MrÂ»
Thomas Lee of Ml Campbell street but
lived with Officer Bert Curtiss for the
past live or six years. Mr. and Mrs
Curtiss were both away from home when
the accident happened, but Officer Cur
tiss answers all calls for the patrol wagon
during the day, hence was on hand to
gather intormation and give directions for
her care. She may not live through the
night.
Mrs. Whiteford died at the Receiving
Hospital late to-night.
POWDER CAN EXPLODES.
Spark From a Forge Ignites the Ex
plosive in a Blacksmith-Shop.
OAKLAND, April I.â W. Lebrecht and
John Foreman, while at work in a black
smith shop on Sixteenth street, near Tel
egraph avenue, this morning, were star
tled by a violent explosion that nearly
wrecked the building and made them
think a second edition of the earthquake
had arrived. The whole building was en
veloped in smoke immediately which
caused a lire alarm to be -sounded
After getting out on the street the gen
tlemen soon learned that there was no
lire, but it required some time to dis
cover the cause of the explosion. When
the smoke had cleared away sufficiently
to enable them to enter again they found
an old ten-pound lard can that had had
powder in it. This Lebrecht and E O
Lufkin had carried on a hunting trip but
Mr. Lebrecht did not know that it had
been left in the shop.
It was the supposition that a spark
dropped into the can, igniting the pow-
Must Appeal or Drop Them.
OAKLAND, April I.â Alameda County
will appear in court - .onday morning and
ask that seven suits be dismissed for lack
of prosecution. They are for recovery of
taxes paid under protest, and were await
ing the decision of Judge Hall in one, in
which he decided against the plaintiff.
So far, they have made no move to ap
peal, and the county will thus force them
to accept the findings as final or take
their appeal. The suits involved are one
Company, two by tne Oakland Consoli
dated Street Railroad Company, two by
the Oakland. San Leandro and Haywards
Electric Railway Company and two by
tho Alameda, Oakland and Piedmont
Electric Railway Company.
ROETH FOUND
NOT GUILTY
The Supervisor Did Not
Misuse County
Funds.
Indictment of Grand Jury Is
Declared to Have No
Foundation.
An Expensive Job to Prove That Ho
Did Not Take a Load of
Wood.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April L
Supervisor Charles E. noeth was ac
quitted of a charge of malfeasance in of
fice by a jury to-day, after half an hour's
deliberation. The prosecution was the
result of an indictment containing several
counts returned by the last Grand Jury-
From the very first Mr. Roeth has con
tended that his indictment was nothing
CHARLES E. ROETH, the Indicted Supervisor, "Who Has Been
Exonerated by a Jury.
but persecution, and has expressed per
fect confidence that he could clear him
self on all points. The jury only took
two ballots, and was then unanimous for
acquittal. The arguments were con
cluded yesterday, and this morning noth
ing remained but for Judge Ellsworth to
instruct the jury. The Instructions were
very brief, and the Judge dwelt espe
cially upon the necessity of giving the
defendant the benefit of the' presumption
of innocence. The court also impressed
tjpon the jurors that they were to banish
any prejudice they might feel and to con
sider nothing but the evidence.
"I am greatly relieved, said Super
visor Roeth, "at the verdict. While I
was confident of the jury's findings, a
man feels less anxious when matters are
settled. I trust now that the public will
know there has been no foundation for
the accusation brought against me. The
evidence was mostly from ignorant
sources and was very much juggled. Now
that the thing is over it seems absurd
that any one ever listened to such gos
sip."
Ex-Mayor Chapman, who was one of
Roeth's attorneys said that the evidence
showed that Roeth not only did not mis
appropriate the county's funds but he
saved the county money. Roeth paid for
some work out of his own pocket which
it is claimed the county paid for.
The trial has been an expensive one for
the county, considering the questions at
issue. One of the chief charges was that
Roeth appropriated about $15 worth of
wood to his own use that oelonged to the
county. To prove that he did not do this
has cost about $558, made up as xollows:
Jurors' fees, $288; reporter, $120; mileage,
$100; service of papers, $50.
STUDENTS WOULD FIGHT SPAIN
Uncle Sam Can Find Ready Sol
diers at the State University.
BERKELEY, April I.â A number of
students at the State University have
signified their intention of offering their
services to the Government in case a war
with Spain is declared.
A list of names of prospective soldiers
was started this morning in the armory.
By this evening eleven students had
signed it. The statement to which the
signatures were affixed is as follows:
"In the event of war with Spain we, the
undersigned, virtually agree and pledge
ourselves to offer our services to the
President of the United States of Amer
ica," The signers so far are: R. W. Ben
der, C. S. Schilling, Paul A.
L. Giacomini, J. W. Millar, B. T. Dow,
R. S. Lavenson, L. T. O'Toole, Edward
Rainey, Spiro F. Sargonlich and A. B.
Anderson. Three of the signers, Gia
comini, Millar and Rainey, are captains
of cadet companies, and .bender and An
derson are lieutenants in a military
organization at Berkeley.
Records May Be Broken.
BERKELEY, April 1.-An athletic car
nival, consisting of the annual univer
sity championship field day and baseball
games between the \ arsity and alumni,
will take place to-morrow afternoon on
the university grounds. The cinder path
has been put in tirst-class condition, and
according to one of the most prominent
of the track athletes there is a strong
probability of Drum breaking the record
in the 220 yard dash and Walsh In the
mile walk. The baseball game promises
to be a close one. The Varsity has been
practicing hard, and the men are in ex
cellent condition, while the alumni will
probably be strengthened by having
Iberg of the California Markets In the
box.
Damage for a Lonely Walk.
OAKLAND, April I.â J. P. Burris haa
filed a suit for $200 damages against the
Realty Syndicate for refusing to carry
him on a transfer issued by one of their
own lines. The trouble occurred on Sep
tember 11, last year, when the Fourth
avenue branch was discontinued at 10:30
p. m. without notice to the patrons. Bur
ris was given a transfer, but there was
no car, and he had to walk a mile and a
half. His wife was ill and he had been
down town purchasing some medicine for
her. The case came to trial to-day be
fore Justice Clift, but went over one
week, after taking part of the testimony.
Will Make No Defense.
OAKLAND. April I.â Joseph H. Moffett
appeared in the Police Court this morning
with his head still in bandages. His at
torney aakÂ«Â»d for an early examination,
stating that ho desired to get his client
out of the unhealthy City Prison to the
"ounty Jail as soon as possible. He fur
ther stated that he would mane no de
fense at the examination; hence it would
require but a short time. Monday after
noon at 2 o'clock was agreed upon by the
counsel and accepted by the court. Thus
far Mrs. Dora Guernsey, Moffet's step
daughter, who swore to the complaint
charging him with murder, is the only
witness subpenaed.
GOOD TIMES
COST MONET
Don Ezeta Now Objects
to Settle With the
Hostess.
Six Months' French Dinners, at
the Apel Chateau . in
. . Alameda.
The Ex-Vice-rPresident of Salvador.
â Also Forgot to Pay Back â¢
Sniall Loans. "â¢'".'.â¢.'
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 1. .-,
General Ezeta, late Vice-Presiderit of
the republic of Salvador, and now of
this city, has been sued for â¢ a paltry
$141 50. The general has been In. the Jus
tice's court before, and his. experience
was such that it was-, thought he would
not care to go through it again. But the
i general is evidently doughty.'
General Ezeta cannot understand why
Americans should be in such a hurry for
their money. The little bill for which he
is now sued was contracted between Feb
ruary and September of last year, and
the general thinks this is very early to
try to collect it by the law. It is a very
interesting bill that the general, is. asked
to pay. "With the exception of one loan
of $20 it consists entirely of "French din
ners for two." â¢â¢â  â¢
There is in Alameda a lady named Mrs.
N. H. Apel, who is noted the country
round for her marvelous menus. Mrs.'
Apel's French dinners enjoy a fame
which reaches clear across the bay, and
it was not long after the general's exile
from Salvador that he discovered this
little resort in Alameda. Last February
the general entered upon a couTse of Apel
dinners that extended for. six months,
eating one regularly about every ten
days. There are eighteen dinners charged
against him and his friend, and the averr
age price is $6 50. . â  ' â â '.'â 
On one occasion In June the general ate
a hilarious dinner, and he is charged with
$15. The details of the dinner are not
given, but a liberal supply of wine was
included. One little item shows that the
general must have been flat broke when
he visited the Apel restaurant, for he
took the lady of the house into his con-,
fidence and was accommodated with. $20
in gold coin, and this is made a' separate
item. All kinds of peaceable attempts
have been made since last September to
collect the biil, but without success. â¢
In September of last year Mrs. Apel
ceased to consider the ex-Vice'-Presiderit
of Salvador "a good thing" any longer,
and he was invited to pay up his arrears
or seek another retreat. He sought an
other retreat, and now Mrs. Apel, tired
of waiting, intends to have the general
up on a plebeian order of examination to
Jind out whether he is in a position or not
to pay for the eighteen French dinners
that he and his friend enjoyed nearly . a
year ago. _______^____^
BARK HUNTER
TO GO NORTH
Taken From Her Berth to Fit
Out for Gold-Hunting
on Rivers.
Will Carry a Small Steamer to Be
Used for Prospecting
Purposes. â 
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 1.
The bark Hunter was towed out of the
creek to-night and taken across the bay
to fit out for Alaska. The bark has been
purchased by a Chicago company, of
which Engineer A. C. Rumble is the local
representative, and will be started north
as soon as possible.
"Our expedition is an entirely new one,"
said Mr. Rumble to-night, "and we do not
expect to do anything but prospect along
the rivers this summer. We have a.
steamer In sections all ready to go north
and with it will go a dredging apparatus
for finding out the depth, value and. na
ture of the bedrocks of the rivers. We'
have a concession of twenty miles on
four rivers from the Canadian Govern
ment" and we believe that they all have
gold in their beds. The original infentlon
was to fit out at Seattle, but I induced
my people to do all the purchasing here
for this purpose wo have bought the
Hunter.
"After prospecting and finding out what
Is needed, we shall come back and have
adequate dredging apparatus built and go
to work in earnest. Thtf Hunter is a
stanch vessel and we have had three sur
veys made and all have been satisfa*
tory. We shall have another one made
as soon as she is off the bank and on
the other side of the bay."
Sophs Remain Silent.
BERKELEY, April I.â The sophomore
class met this morning and again refused
to take action in regard to rushing. A
resolution pledging not to rush the fresh
men on the day of their Bourdon celebra
tion was tabled, as was also a proposition
to hold an opposition demonstration on
the campus. The freshmen will hold their
celebration on April 29.

"BEER BUST"
AT BERKELEY
A Methodist Paper Makes
Charges Against
... Students..
Declares That Some of the
Revelers Became Beastly
Drunk.
Editpr Matthew Protests Agairisl
tho. Revival of * "Serrii
â¢â¢/' Heathen Orgie.'V': \
BERKELEY. April I.â An editorial to
day in the California Christian Advocate
charging that recently a "beer-bust" was
held on the Berkeley campus, at which
a number of students became ."beastly;
drunk v " has created considerable com
ment at the university. The editorial in
question is headed, "Berkeley's. Disgrace,"
It recounts the former, experience which
the Berkeley faculty had with, the "beei
bust" sotne years . ago and calls on . the
president and faculty to put a stop, to the
gradual movement which, is said to have
recently begun to re-establish the objec?
tionable Institution..; Editor ..Matthew
criticizes the recent occurrence as fol-
lows:. â¢''. 'â¢ . ' â¢ â  ... : . : ' ". ; -. 'â  ;'
Years ago students, of. the University, of Cali
fornia inaugurated an annual observance which,
. thf-y .were pleased to call the "Beer Bust.' !
Presumably it. was copied after some semi
heathen .orgie of medieval Gerinahy. : in; no
other, part 6f the American continent have we
ever heard of a. similar observance among stu
dents. The custom was tolerated until it be
came so. disgraceful that the then president of
the university determined to break it up. The
students were warned and. most obeyed..th e in
junction. A few. disobeyed and were brought
to account. .As we now . remember, several
were, suspended arid two ..or fhreis were ex
pelled. That bo incensed certain brewers of
influence that they determined to drive the
hlKh-minded president: from his seat, and they
Fuec-e.ededâ but from his. day the â¢''Beer Bust"
was outlawed. 'â¢;'â .: â¢'". .'â¢ 'â '.
. ' Indeed; until .-recently we supposed it had
passed away forever. Little by little, how
â ever, it: has crept back; and last week, on the
â evening before the. Charter day celebration, a
secluded nook on the Berkeley campus was the
scene of a most disgraceful revel. During the
day tickets were, quletry sold to students who
wished to engage in the carousal,, a quantity of
bfpr was- procured, and late at night a large
n-iimber of studentsâ report saya la(>â cam* to
gether and drank until not a lew were "beast
ly drunk." ; â  â â â  â¢' '-. â : ' ';â¢ : â â '- - : â¢. â  'â â  ':. â¢; â  .
We. are. sure the revelers of last week do not
â¢represent the students. In any ; >r sense. The
vast majority loathe such conduct/ It is, as
one Ftudein says, an expression of all. that is
beastly in the very scunV of student society.
We trust the great body of Christian students
at Berkeley will put on. record their protest
against such barbarism by their fellow stu
dents. And can we not . rely, upon President
Kellogg and the faculty to purge the university
of students ; who haye so low a. sense of
â  decency and honor 7 â '.-.'. '.:"â¢'.â 
Investigation' shows that there Is some
baisis for the statements made in the edi
torial, but It is .maintained that the facts
have been grossly â¢ exaggerated. It is
olainted that nobody was "beastly drunk"
and that. the individuals Wha participated
in the affair-Were mostly: outsiders who
had gone, upon the hill at the back of the
university in the. expectation, of seeing
a rush between the freshmen arid sopho
moTes, the sophomores having started out
to place their cluss number fln the hill.
Neither Editor Matthew, who lives in
. North Berkeley, nor President: Kellogg
could be seen this evening. The latter
is attending . the annual session, of the
Southern. California Teachers' Associa
ti,on. ' . He will not .return to- Berkeley
until, next week.' â  \ '. : ;
Another Damage Suit.
OAKLAND, April Lâ Mrs. Isabella
Purvis has. filed a suit, for $30,000 damages
against the Oakland, San Leandro and
Haywards Electric Railroad. She was
Injured^ on East Fourteenth street, Just
.â east of Thirteenth avenue, on .September
4;. 1897, when an outgoing car jumped the
track at a. switch and struck an inbound
e;ir. Several' persons wÂ«Â»re slightly in
jured, but Mrs. Pufyis received the most
severe shock.. She was laid up for eight
weeks as a result of. the injury.

To Be Courtmartiated.
ALAMEDA, April .I.â At the annual
muster of . Company G last Friday, five
of the members, failed to appear as or
dered. Three of them will be courtmar
tialed, so Captain Simpson announced last
evening, while the other two had sum-
Clent reason for . their, absence. At last
night's meeting the captain told the com
pany that it was a shame that in view
of the present emergency any man should
absent himself from inspectibn when or
dered, and that it has been decided to
make an example of the absentees by
courtniartialing them.
Police Report.
ALAMETTA; April I.â Tho police of thia
city made only thirty arrest's, all told,
last month. Of these eight were for dis
turbing the peace, five for drunkenness,
seven for VagTancy and eight forviolating
city ordinances. Twenty-four vagrants
were furnished- with lodgings and forty
two meals were supplied.

Hopper Waxes Wroth.
BERKELEY, April I.â Editor Hopper
in to-day's Occident strongly denounces
a supposed correspondent of the Ynle
Alumni Weekly at the University of Cali
fornia, who sent to that paper a derisive
article on the recently dedicated "Senior
C." The unknown writer, w-ho, Hopper
believes, la a Yale alumnus at Berkeley, is
scored as follows:
"The Senior C may be ridiculous, may
be an evirnp'e of our childishnfss in
seeking to manufacture college customs;
our athletic methods may be immensely
funny. But we want the man who thinks
so to say so in our faces, and not to make
us ridiculous before strangers. Such pro
ceeding ia treacherous and cowardly. We
have given our opinion of such an indi
vidual and we think that, if ever found,
he will discoverâ be he student, Janitor or
professorâ that, with many faults, there
is enough college spirit and force of opin
ion here at the college of which he is a
member and which he bo maliciously de
rides to make his position absolutely un
tenable."
New Athletic Constitution.
BERKELEY, April I.â Representative
James Hopper, who was appointed by the
executive committee of the Athletic As
soiclatlon to draw up, in conjunction with
Prof essor â  Edwards, a new constitution
for the association, stated that the draft
ing of the document had just been com
pleted, and that it would be presented to
the committee at its next meeting. "The
proposed new constitution," he said, "is
in general a codification of existing regu
lations, the principal new feature being
the provision for a paid and bonded treas
urer and the enlargement of the powers,
not of any individual, but of the athletic
committee.."
Will Play Tennis.
BERKELEY, April 1. â The annual
championship tennis tournament of the
University of California will begin to
morrow at 8:30 a. m. at the Madison
court, Oakland. It ia expected that all
but the final games will be played to
morrow. ..Those who lose to champions
will subsequently play a tournament to
decide second place. The drawings for
the singles are as follows: Kline and
Trysler, Fay and Hovey, Hunter and
Hardy. Dickson and Van Wyck, Brown
arid O'Brien. Stone and Freeman, Solby
and Eckarti Mem and Whitcomb, The
doubles. w(ll not be played for some time.

WENT BROKE
ON MAY W
Tea Rose Led the Calgary
Sprinter Over the
Mark.
Rubicon Finally Showed Some
of His Old-Time
Speed.
FoiMOVinnilh Osi-vo at Pleasant Reoi
talâFavor iteja Took Throo
Purses.
Three of the most useful tools in the
hor?A racing business indulged in a Jaunt
at ingieside tra.-k yesterday. They were
all of -the feminine persuasion and are
known to the tuff as Tea Rose 111, May
W. and Trolley.. The trio met in the after
jilere, a five-furlong scramble. In the
past, May W looked to. have the "Injun"
Fieri on the other two, and the. highly
educated ones made her a 7 to 10 favorita.
Bookmaker Joe. Rose and the racing firm
â A of Atkiit & .' I-rtttrid'ee seemed to. be im
pressed with the Idea that Tea Rose was
thÂ» right thing, and while everybody was
busy getting aboard Trolley arid May W,
the gentlemen niuned backed the Midlo
thian filly. They were correct in their
prognostications, for. Tea Rosn led from
â /the first Jump, and at the wire beat May
AY out over two lengths in track record
time, 1:00^. Trolley "dogged" it badly the
last quarter; . â 'â¢ â  â¢ â¢
Of the. other events decided the favor
ites captured three. James Tod Sloan
participated in six racos. and managed to
â¢finish first on one occasion.' He is un
doubtedly a great r'der on a good horse,
: but on an even hrtak there are other
pabie men in the saddle:
Rubicon finally became affected with
that turf disease termed speed, and
'turned it loose In the mile run, fifth on
the card. His owner, j'om McGowan,
laid his checks down good and thick in
the ring at odds, of 3 to 1. and the Viig
chestnut horse led throughout, downing
Xewsgatherer a neck at thÂ« wire. Grady,
the favorite, finished fourth.
The fast filly Celoso appears to have
lost her form entirely. She was made an
even money favorite over a band of crabs
Jn the opening six-furlong run, and after
displaying a sharp turn of speed for half
a dozen panels, fell out of it. At the end
.All Smoke won by half a length from
Naranja, the second choice, with Sloan
up. The winner was at one time 20 to 1
In the ring.
The .Vpache gelding Native Son repeat
ed his victory of Wednesday by downing
quite a bunch of. youngsters in the three
and one-half furlong spin, going to the
.post a 2to 1 favorite. While Cold Scratch
and l>a Parasseuse were lighting it out
the last part, Sloan got up with the favor
ite, winning by less than a length. La
Parasseuse quit, permitting Thorpe to
get the place with Gold Scratch.
The wise money sent Ponsovannah to
the post favorite for the. seven-furlong
run, and a splendid piece of riding on the
part of "Skeets" Martin got the money
for midreth's oojt Lord Marmion made
. the running in front to the paddock
where Martin collared him with the first
choice, and then, stalling off Sloan's chal
lenge with Sardonic,. got the verdict over
the latter by. a head in 1:27)4. Mklian the
second choice, was left at the post
Hut six went to the post in the mile
and a quarter run, decided under selling
conditions. AJvarado ruled favorite, and
overhauling Song and Dance the last six
teenth, won all out by a head in 2:09 Dr
Marks finished in tin- show-
TRACK ITEMS.
. The $5000 California Derby will be the feature
of the card this afternoon. ' The. best three
year-olds in training will face the barrier, and
It should prove a rare drawing card.
Bid Reagan gets Hermoso. J. A. Grey did not
produce the coin yesterday that was paid him
when the colt was claimed, and has no longer
any claim on the sprinter.!
â  .Tod Sloan, probably' the greatest rider that
.ever straddled a horse outside of ' "Snapper"
â¢Garrison, Jimmy Mclaughlin,'- Isaac Murphy,
Fred Archer, "Morny" Cannon, Patsy Duffy'
Willie Martin and- others,- will -depart for the
East on Tuesday next. His' Excellency Gover
nor Budd has not yet proclaimed the occasion a
national holiday, presumably for the reason
that the. Cuban crisis has absorbed His atten
tion. No doubt an apology will be forth
coming. â  . . â¢ . ' â : ' . :â¢â¢'â¢â¢
The Pacific- Coast Jockey Club Is making a
determined^ fight against the poolroom evil,
Yesterday the Western Union Telegraph Com
rany's operators were, absent from their posts
telegraphic communication bOlng' entirely cut
off from the track.

Burglars in the Mission.
Last Wednesday afternoon burglars
entered the residence of James Maher at
2727 Mission street and stole a pair of
opera glasses and a mandolin. An en
trance was gained by opening the front
door with a skeleton key. The .burg
lary was last night reported to the police.

street, sells â¢'STANDARD" shirts. â¢

THE SAX FRAXCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1898.
BUILDING AN
ARMY BRIDGE
National Guardsmen Erect a
Structure Without Ham
mer or Nails.
This Will Be One of the Features of
the Military Display of the
First Infantry.
One of the features of the military dis
play to be given by the companies of the
First Infantry Regiment at the Mechan
ics' Pavilion on the evening of the 22d
inst., will be the building of a bridge
by Company B, Captain George Filmer.
At a practice drill held in the old First
armory on Market street, Thursday
night, by the members of the company
named, there was a demonstration how
soldiers can build a bridge inside of half
an hour without using a nail or hammer,
and making it strong enough for an army
to pass over.
The particular bridge has a fifteen foot
approach on each side of the imaginary
ravine, the bridge proper is twenty-four
feet long and eight feet wide, and is sup
ported in the center from the apex beam
of a truss formed by four by six beams,
the ends of which rest on each side of the i
ravine. The whole structure is of beams, J
planks and three-quarter inch ropes used
for lashings.
Heavy chalk marks on the floor desig
nate the two sides of the ravine or gully
over which none of the builders are per
mitted to step during the building. At
each side close to this line stand a team
of men each having two pieces of rope
over their shoulders, and by the side of
each team are three pieces of ten-foot
timber partly rounded. At the word of
command each team goes to work to lash
the ends of the three pieces of timber
together in such a manner that when
l>la<x-d upright on the free ends they
form a tripod. These four tripods are.
placed at indicated spots, and at a point
three feet from the bottom the teams lash
three by three inch pieces of wood so aa
to form a triangle. These triangles form
the base of support for the cross timbers
on which to rest the floor beams, and
tlip greater the weight the firmer is the
lushing and the more solid the tripods.
While the teams of three men each are
doing this, two other teams are busy
lashing a heavy cross timber to each end
of long beams, one foot from the end.
L.ike work is done on each side of the
ravine. When these are properly lashed, !
the pieces held by guy ropes at the top I
each guided by one man, are brought to
a vertical position and carried forward
by a strong force of men until the foot
of each timber rests against one of the
tripods. Then the beams are lowered
slowly, simultaneously, until they meet
over the center of the ravine, when one
cross beam rests on the other and there
is a perfect truss. Two men climb up !
the sides of the truss and by means of
ropea haul to the apex a four by four !
piece ten feet long which they place in j
the crotch formed by the timbers, lashed !
that firmly, and from the ends fixed guy .
ropes, the loose ends of which are swung i
to the edges.
These being caught are formed
into a loop and in this is placed a heavy
square timber that is allowed to swing
toward the center and in time become the
center support of the bridge. The two
end cross beams being lashpd to the tri
angle of the tripods a twenty-four foot
four by six beam is launched from one
side of the ravine toward the other side.
There is the struggle of the work, for
the men who pu?h the beam have but
little purchase, but by clever maneuver
ing on the other side and a little gym
nafltic exercise the free end is caught by
one of the men and held until it was
shoved over far enough to allow that end
to rest on the other cross beam. The
Bide pieces being in place they are firmly
lashed, a piece of ash wood "is placed in
each of the slings, the ropes are twisted
and by that means the heavy timber at
the bottom of the slings is brought to
Its proper level, the ends secured, and i
the ends of the ash sticks are also se- j
cured. Then it is easy and quick work j
to place in position the timbers for the I
approaches, the floor beams, lash them
â  ,>â¢â  Â»'-â flooring, after which
the bridsre Is ready for use. The boys
have been practicing twice a week for
several weeks, and they expect on ex
hibition nl^ht to be able to put the
bridge together in twenty minutes, and
have it ready in that time for the en
tire regiment to walk over it. The prac
tice reflects great credit on the men,
nearly all of whom are clerks In stores.
Dentists Dine and Discourse.
The Sigma Chapter of the Delta Sigma
Delta Fraternity of the University of
California College of Dentistry held its
seventh annual banquet at the California
Hotel last night. The table was beauti
fully decorated, and, while a string band
charmed away dull care with a number
of lively selections, the guests occupied
themselves in charming away the numer
ous good things that Mine Host Warfield
had provided for their delectation. When
the inner man had received sufficient at
tention Dr. 11. C. Carlton, acting as toast
master, called for order and Introduced a
number of speakers, who had come pre
pared to do, and who did, themselves and
the occasion proud.

THE California Debris Commission, having
received applications to mine by the hy-
draulic process from William Nolden and C.
Kaber, in the Aureole mine, near Oleta,
Amador County, to deposit tailings In Dead-
man Creek, and from George Beattle, In the
Beattle mine at Georgia Slide. El Dorado
County, to deposit tailings behind the dam
of the Gold Bug mine In Canyon Creek, gives
notice that a meeting will be held at room
69, Flood building. San Francisco, Cal., on
April 11. IS9S. at 1:30 p. m.

RAN PULPIT
AND BAR IN
TENDERLOIN
Charles Montgomery
as Proprietor of the
Silver State.
Ned Foster and J. T. Wise
man "Were His Busi
ness Partners.
Neither Transient Rooms Nor
Whisky Sales Proved
Profitable.
THE HELP WAS NOT PAID.
Aged Salvation Evangelist Withdrew
When Business Became
Dull.
The Silver State Hotel on Mason
street, a well-known and popular re
sort to those who frequent the tender
loin, has just furnished a strange illus
tration of the fact that business am
bitions and methods often make bed
fellows of men of the most dissimilar
tastes.
It is not perhaps generally known to
the public that there have recently
been quarrels amnnsr the managers of
the place and that S. Silverberg, the
A. Block of Stock in the Silver State Hotel Company, Showing
That Charles Montgomery, the Evangelist, Was President
of the Concern.
owner, has had a hard battle to get
possession of his property.
J. T. Wiseman, well known in. the
sporting circles of the city; Ned Foster,
with a long record as proprietor of the
Bella Union and a "good fellow" on
the turf, and Charles Montgomery, the
well-known Salvation evangelist, ran
the Silver State until lately, Montgom
ery's name appearing in the city di
rectory as manager. Various people
who did business with the house when
Charles Montgomery was president and
Wiseman was secretary of the incor
poration, say they had great trouble in
collecting their bills. While the bar and
rooms were paying best Mr. Montgom
ery preached nightly in the basement.
Though Mr. Montgomery, last night
denied that he had been in any manner
connected with the place since last
July, Ned Foster, Contractor Becker,
who built the house; J. Leland, the
Ned Foster Transfers Silver State
Stock.
bellboy, and others, who were at the
house dally, said that Montgomery and
Wiseman called at the desk every day
until two months ago to get their share
of the earnings of the whole house, and
this included, at stated times, rent
from the bar as well as the daily re
ceipts from the rooms frequented by a
class 61 transients well known to the
police.
Most of the paying business of the
house was from transient trade, accord
ing to those most familiar with the pat
ronage that kept it up. While Mr.
Montgomery preached down stairs in
the basement there was always a merry
Jingle of coin over the bar above, and
the hotel clerk took in a pretty good
income from the trade in rooms. It was
the custom of Messrs. Wiseman and
Montgomery to divide the money at 1
o'clock each day.
The business did not thrive very well,
in spite of the fact that the lessees of
the barroom and restaurant said that

many of their bills were collected by
the corporation and never turned over
to them, so Ned Foster, having a wide
acquaintance with the class of people
likely to cater to the goods sold at the
hotel, was induced to buy some stock.
At a meeting attended by Messrs.
Wiseman and Montgomery, as well as
by some of the stockholders Ned was
elected president of the company, but
he found so many debts that it was
hard to make a ship sail smoothly.
He tried to settle matters "on the
square," but found it a bad entangle
ment all through.
Meantime Landlord Silverberg found
that the concern owed him $1200 in
rent. When he appealed to the new
president to settle it the old Bella
Union manager winked and said, "I am
surprised that these people have sold
me stock when they owe debts. Of
course I know nothing of this."
The matter was compromised by
Landlord Silverberg, who is eager
for a new management. He gave a re
ceipt in full for the rent and paid Presi
dent Montgomery and Secretary Wise
man $350 to vacate the premises. Ned
Foster still holds the foTt, as does J.
B. Leland, proprietor of the bar.
Mrs. Gale, formerly of 17 Stockton
street, is now conducting the hotel
along the same lines as those pursued
by Mr. Montgomery and his associates,
though she says she will pay her help.
Ned Foster still claims to be presi
dent of the company, though he has
Bold a great deal of his stock to his
wife and others. Landlord Silverberg
feels better that he has the house run
ning under the new management.
When Charles Montgomery was seen
regarding the matter last night he
said: "The fact is I quit the hore!
when they opened up the oar, and I
have had nothing to do with it since
last July. I could not stand the sa
loon business, and I think a pretty
hard crowd has succeeded me, as I
hear they are running a saloon."
HOME MISSIONS.
San Francisco Presbyterian Home
Missionary Society Holds Its
Annual Meeting.
Officers for the ensuing year were
elected at the annual meeting of the San
Francisco Presbyterial Home Missionary
Society at the Mizpah Presbyterian
Church yesterday. The ladies who will
take charge for twelve months will be:
Mrs. T. J. Ames, president: Mrs. R. B.
Goddard. vice-president: Miss E. Lunt,
recording secretary'; Miss Anna Smart,
secretary; Mrs. T. C. Pedlar, treasurer.
I The treasurer's report for the past year
showed that $2000 had been expended by
the society for home missions and that
there was $181 more than last year In the
treasury.
The session, which lasted all day and
evening, was occupied by the following
